item.title: Tomorrow, When The War Began
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tomorrow When The War Began verteld het verhaal van Ellie Linton (Caitlin Stasey). Ze gaat met een groep vrienden kamperen in een verlaten gebied. 's Nachts vliegen een hele hoop legervliegtuigen over hun en als ze terugkeren naar huis, is iedereen verdwenen. Ze komen er al snel achter dat hun familie en buren gevangen genomen zijn en dat een leger van een ander (voor hen onbekend) land, Australië overnomen heeft.. Het is oorlog en ze doen er alles aan om te winnen. De film is gebaseerd op een boek van John Marsden en is de eerste uit een reeks. De tweede en derde film zijn ook al aangekondigd. Ik moet zeggen dat ik aangenaam verrast was door deze film! Het verhaal sprak me enorm aan. Oké, het is misschien niet erg realistisch, maar dat speelt voor mij niet zo'n grote rol. De cast is mij niet geheel onbekend. Caitlin Stasey ken ik uit "The Sleepover Club", een tv serie waar ik als kind naar keek en Phoebe Tonkin speelde in deze film de blonde versie van haar rol in "H2O: Just Add Water" (ook een reeks die ik als kind volgde). Rachel Hurd-Wood herken ik ook van haar rol in "Dorian Gray". Het acteertalent van deze cast was misschien niet van de hoogste plank, maar het stoorde mij niet zo erg. Dit is gewoon een film waar je kan van genieten als je geen te hoge verwachtingen hebt. Punt uit. Ik weet alvast dat ik enorm uitkijk naar de vervolgen!

Trailer | IMDb

item.title: Shameless Plug: District12.be - A Hunger Games Fansite
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: District12.be, een fansite van fans, voor fans over de film The Hunger Games, die gebaseerd is op een boekenreeks van Suzanne Collins. Onze fansite is nog maar net geopend en we zijn nog volop bezig met alle pagina's aan te vullen. We wilden jullie echter wel al op de hoogte kunnen houden van het laatste Hunger Games-nieuws, dus vandaar deze tijdelijke layout! Nu ook de verfilming van het tweede boek, Catching Fire, officieel is, kijken wij enorm uit naar de komende jaren vol Hunger Games en wij hopen dit met jullie te kunnen delen!

item.title: Q Showcase met Selah Sue
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Hallo allemaal (of moet ik zeggen niemand?) en nog een gelukkig 2012 gewenst. Mijn verontschuldigingen voor het niet-bloggen of updaten van de website. Ik ben gewoon zo druk geweest met andere dingen, dat het er nooit echt van kwam. Ik betwijfel eerlijk gezegd of iemand deze website nog wel bezoekt. Nee, ik weet het eigenlijk wel zeker. Google Analytics wist het me te vertellen. Hoe dan ook, kan het nooit geen kwaad om nogmaals een poging te doen om terug leven in de website te krijgen. Zo heb is gisteren een concert mogen bijwonen, wat toch wel iets is om te delen :). Ik zit momenteel midden in mijn examens en een tijdje terug kondigde Q-music aan dat ze een showcase gingen organiseren met niemand minder dan Selah Sue. Moest je toevallig nog wel eens een blog van mij gelezen hebben deze zomer, dan weet je misschien dat ik haar al een keer live aan het werk had gezien op TW Classic 2011. Een festival is echter niet te vergelijken met een concert, dus ik wilde haar heel graag nog eens live zien. Enkele maanden terug stond een optreden van haar gepland in België, maar om een reden die ik zelf niet meer weet, kon ik niet aanwezig zijn op dat concert. Wedstrijden van Q-music (een radiostation in België), gebeuren meestal via de radio zelf aan de hand van sms'en of bellen. Ik had echter al wel gemerkt dat ze soms ook de kans geven om via de website deel te nemen. Dat was voor de showcase ook het geval! Toen ik de vraag las die je moest beantwoorden, dacht ik 'ik kan maar evengoed meedoen, want winnen ga ik toch niet doen'. Ze vroegen om te schatten hoeveel unieke bezoekers hun website zou hebben op een bepaalde dag. Hopeloos zijn zo'n vragen! Een tijdje later zat er echter een mailtje van Q in mijn mailbox, om me te vertellen dat ik gelukkige winnaar was van een duoticket! Gisteren, 19 januari, vond de showcase plaats. Vanmorgen had ik nog een examen, maar het was niet zo'n moeilijk vak. Dus had ik het risco genomen om de avond voor mijn examen nog naar het optreden van Selah Sue te gaan! Het was het helemaal waard om naar Vilvoorde te rijden, met mijn zus aan mijn zij, want het optreden was werkelijk puur genieten! Ik hou van haar stem en haar energie op het podium!

item.title: Downton Abbey (TV Show Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Downton Abbey is een Brits kostuumdrama. De serie speelt zich af in het fictieve Downton Abbey, het statige huis van de graaf en gravin van Grantham, en volgt de levens van de aristocratische familie Crawley en hun bedienden in de vroege regeerperiode van Koning George V. (bron: Wikipedia) Iets wat mij voornamelijk aantrok aan de serie was dat Maggie Smith er een rol in heeft en haar toch wel eens in een andere rol wilde zien dan 'Professor McGonagall'. Ik ben verder best kieskeurig als het op kostuumdrama's aankomt. Hoe dan ook, ik heb mezelf aan de eerste aflevering gezet en ben blijven verder kijken. Het is een mini-series, dus jammer genoeg bestaat elk seizoen maar uit 7 à 8 afleveringen. Ik ben nog maar net aan het tweede seizoen kunnen beginnen (wegens examens), maar ik wilde het alvast aanraden aan naar wie wil luisteren of misschien een beetje interesse heeft. Wat mij vooral aantrek aan de serie is dat je zowel het leven dan Lord en Lady Grantham, hun kinderen en de rest van de familie te zien krijgt, alsook het leven van hun 'servants'. Omdat ik toch niet zo sterk ben in het schrijven van een deftige review, staat hieronder een linkje naar de promo van het eerste seizoen.

Seizoen 1 Promo | IMDb

item.title: A new beginning
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Finally, my new and improved portfolio website is up and running! Those who've been visiting my site regularly will notice quite a big change. The whole site was transformed. Both the look and the content have changed. As you've probably noticed already, the site is in English now. I still have my old (Dutch) posts up at the moment, but I might remove some because there'll be a lot of dead links in them by now (and nobody likes that).
I do plan on making this website responsive as well, but I haven't had time for that so far and I really wanted the new design to be up asap.
The plan is to actually use the blog this time around! I plan to blog about all things web design, thing I learn or discover, etc. Every once in a while I'll write some reviews about books and movies and stuff and I'll also blog about projects I'm working on.
I don't know what else to say, so I suggest to take a look around and leave me some feedback in the comments!

item.title: Designosource
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I thought this would be a good time to introduce my graduate project: Designosource. Designosource is a practice enterprise that was started by a few of my teachers within my study. Every year, students can apply to be a part of the Designosource team and the teachers make their selection. I'm a part of this years team. In September the teachers basically handed over their little company to us, the students, and they guide us along the way. At our first meeting we got a short introduction of the projects we'll be working on this year. Some are internal projects (clients from within the school), there's a charity project, a government assignment and more. We are a team of 12 students and 4 teachers. For each project our team gets split up into teams of 6. I plan on blogging about the projects I'm a part of, depending on their progress. So far there's not much to show, as most projects are still in an early stage. We are currently in the process of redesigning our website. The plan is to get the new site up and running in two weeks. Until then, you can keep an eye on us on Facebook and Twitter.

item.title: The Casual Vacancy (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I have to admit that I was scared to read The Casual Vacancy. I have been a Harry Potter fan for as long as I can remember and I've always admired J.K. Rowling. When I first read the synopsis of the book, I realized that this wasn't going to be the kind of book that I normally read. To be honest, I wouldn't even have looked twice at this book, if it hadn't been written by Rowling. But she did write it and I just couldn't ignore this book. I had to pick it up and read it. Luckily, I wasn't disappointed! Even though it took be almost a month to finish reading this book, I enjoyed it very much! The Casual Vacancy follows the lives of people in a small town, after the death of Barry Fairbrother. The book has so many characters that I was afraid that I'd be hard to keep up, but the book is so well written that you can easily keep up with who is who. The character development in this book is so fascinating! Each character has its flaw, but they're all very interesting to read about. I became emotionally attached to some of them! I loved the writing style, but that doesn't take away that it was a bit slow at times. I enjoyed the beginning of the book, but I was wondering where the story was going and I had an especially hard time somewhere half-way through. The last 100 to 200 pages made up for that, though, but I do wish the whole book was as amazing as those last pages. The Casual Vacancy isn't for everyone. I think this book is worth reading, but I'm quite sure not everyone will enjoy it. As a massive fan of the Harry Potter series, I'm glad that I enjoyed this book. I give it 4 out of 5 stars. If you've read The Casual Vacancy, feel free to let me know what you thought of it in the comments.

item.title: Soep 't erin (Designosource Project)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Soep 't erin is one of the projects of Designosource and I thought I'd already introduce this one to you. Every year Designosource takes on one charity project and this year that project is Soep 't erin (I can't translate the name, sorry). Soep 't erin is a project of an organisation called Pegode. Pegode works with people with disabilities and starting in December, they will sell soup to the people in their neighborhood. However, it's more than just selling soup. They are growing all of the vegetables for the soup themselves, harvesting them and making the soup. They will drive around in a carriercycle and sell it. Selling the soup is also a way for them to network and interact with the people around them. Designosource is making a couple of promotion videos and a website, but because they've already started promoting the project, we set up a temporary website that counts down 'till the start of the project. Visit the temporary Soep 't erin website. I am part of the website team. I created the countdown page, based on the mock-up that my colleagues created for the actual website. The logo was made by someone else. I'll be sure to let you know when the site has launched! Feel free to let me know what you think of this project and the temporary website.

item.title: Bloodlines (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I cannot believe that I had doubts about reading the Bloodlines series by Richelle Mead! Bloodlines is set in the same world as Vampire Academy and I loved the VA-series and its characters so much, that I didn't really want to read another series in that world, with other characters. But I tried it anyway and ended up falling in love all over again. Vampire Acadamy and Bloodlines are set in a Vampire world. There are Moroi (the mortal vampires), Dhampirs (half-vampire, half-human and they protect the Moroi) and Strigoi (the immortal vampires). Bloodlines follows Sydney. She is an Alchemist (they clean up the mess the vampires make). Sydney's character was already introduced in Vampire Acadamy. I already quite liked her in VA, but I ended up loving her in Bloodlines. Sydney was thaught to have certain believes about vampires and their magic and it is both crazy and admiring to see her commitment to those believes. One thing I love about the Bloodlines, is that Adrian is in it! He's such a great character and always brings funny moments to the story. It was also nice to get to know Jill and Eddie a little better and of course Rose's little appearance. The plot was also really interesting, though, maybe a little predictable at times. If you haven't read Vampire Academy and you don't mind some vampires once in a while, then I suggest you give the series a try. It's an amazing world and Richelle Mead is a great writer. And after those 6 books, you can start reading the Bloodlines series! I give Bloodlines 4 out of 5 stars.

item.title: A Bunch of Awesome Movie Trailers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
As a bookworm and a movie fanatic, I like it when my favorite books are being made into a movie. Yes, the book always ends up being better than the movie, but that doesn't mean that I can't enjoy seeing these stories come to live. Over the past month, a couple of trailers got released for movies of which I have read the books. The trailer releases got me really excited to see the movies and I wanted to share my thoughts on them with you (and maybe convince you the check them out too).

The Host

The Host is a science fiction, love story. The book was written by Stephenie Meyer, author of The Twilight Saga. Don't let the word 'Twilight' make you say 'no' right away, though! The Host is something completely different and a million times better than Twilight. I'm not yet convinced about the cast of this movie, expect for Saoirse Ronan (she's awesome). I'll just have to wait and see the movie, before I judge the cast. I do think the trailer looks pretty awesome! The movie will be in theaters on March 29th, 2013 in the USA and in Belgium on April 3rd, 2013.

The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones

It's been a while since I've read City of Bones, but that doesn't make me any less excited. I suggest you watch the trailer to learn what the story is about, because I can't explain it in one sentence. After seeing the trailer, I got more faith in the casting choices. I didn't quite know what to think of everyone when the cast got announced, but the trailer looks really promising. The movie is set to release on August 23rd, 2013 in the USA.

Warm Bodies

I read Warm Bodies this September. It had been on my to-read-list for a while now and with the movie release coming closer, I thought it'd be the perfect time to read it. I think Warm Bodies is the first zombie book I ever read and I loved it! It's such a fascinating story to read. Judging by the trailer, they gave a funny/comedic twist to the story, which I think is perfect! Warm Bodies is being released on the 1st of February, 2013 in the States.

Beautiful Creatures

And last but not least: Beautiful Creatures! This is another great Young Adult book. I read the book a few years ago, so I don't remember all of the details. I know that they changed a few things going into the movie. They changed some of the characters and maybe some other stuff. I don't want to ruin the movie for myself, though, so I'm not re-read the book. The movie is coming out on February 13th, 2013 in America and on March 6th, 2013 in Belgium. Let me know if you're looking forward to any of these movies? Have you read the books? To you plan to read them?

item.title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 is the final Twilight movie ever(!) and I'm not sad about it. I knew in advance that they had made some changes to the ending of the movie. I thought that they had changed it into the ending I was missing in the book, but I got something completely unexpected. First things first. The movie started with some credits, which I thought was a bit weird. The images were beautiful and all that, but it almost felt like they were saying goodbye before the movie had even started. Now, the actual movie. I wasn't that impressed with Bella as a vampire. I think I enjoyed her first hunting scene more in book than in the movie. Then the baby, Renesmee, was created with CGI, but it looked very creepy and unreal. It pulled me out of the story every single time, because I was just focusing on how weird she looked. One of the scenes I was looking forward to, was the arm wrestling scene between Bella and Emmett and it was a very fun moment. I loved that Emmett had a little more to say in this movie, than the previous ones, because he's got some funny lines and Kellan Lutz is just so likable! Than to the plot twist at the end. I'll try to explain this without spoiling anything, but feel free to skip this paragraph if you really don't want to get any hints whatsoever. So when the fight started, I thought that we would finally see how Twilight should've ended but they took a bit of an unexpected approach. I though the first half of the fight was ok, but at a certain point some things started to happen that just didn't make any sense to me. And than the unexpected thing happened. The last scene of the movie, is one of my favorite Edward/Bella moments and it was also my favorite scene of the movie. It was great to see the flashbacks and that in combination with Christina Perri's song made it perfect! In the end, I left with a double feeling. I'm not crazy about Breaking Dawn - Part 2, but I don't think it was bad either. Twilight has now come to an end and like I said, I'm not sad about it. I also don't regret the early years when I was a massive fan, because someone reminded me a few days ago, that I met some of my best friends because of The Twilight Saga. So all in all, it was a great five years. Let me know your thoughts about The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 down below!

item.title: Florence and the Machine @ Lotto Arena, Antwerp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Because the site was down all day yesterday, this blog is up with a bit of a delay, but better late than never. On November 25th, Florence and the Machine came to the Lotto Arena in Antwerp, Belgium as a part of their Ceremonials tour. I've wanted to see the band live for quite a few years now and after failing to get tickets for their concert in Brussels of earlier this year, I was more than excited when they announced another concert in Belgium! And I wasn't let down! On the contrary, Florence and the Machine exceeded all of my expectations and I had the best time! Florence Welch is such a charismatic and impressive woman and her voice is brilliant. The way she included the audience was great. After her second song, she already asked the people in the balconies to stand up and dance and all the way through the show, she bounced back and forward on the stage, interacting with the crowd. Florence told us how much she loved Antwerp and how beautiful the city is. She also said that they got lost and some people who recognized them, gave them a lift back to their hotel (if only I'd been around to give them a lift). I don't think that there's much more for me to say. I had an amazing time, I enjoyed the music and I definitely think its worth repeating! If you've ever seen Florence + The Machine live, feel free to share you experience in the comments. If you haven't seen them live, tell me if you would want to!

item.title: WJEC (Designsource Project)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Today was a bit of a special day, because the first Designosource project went live today! The World Journalism Education Congress (WJEC) is a journalism congress, organized by the journalism education of my school. I was part of the team who had the honor of renewing their website. I created the design, then Ewout applied his HTML + CSS skills to it and I made a Wordpress theme out of that. Joeri and I discover the world of content types and views within Wordpress. That way we made it easier for the client to add new hotels (see page) and sponsors (see page) to their website. I guess that there's not much more for me to say, so go ahead and visit WJEC and let me know what you think! Oh and we already took the time to celebrate with the whole Designosource team and the client!

item.title: Soep 't erin went live!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A little while ago, I already introduced Soep 't erin (one of the projects of Designosource). Now I am happy to announce that the website went live! So what did we do? As I already said in my previous blog about this project, we were asked to make promotion videos and a website. So far, only one of the videos is posted on the website. The second one is finished and the third and final one is on the way. I was one of the people who worked on the website for Soep 't erin. The design was made by Geoffrey and Max. I wrote most of the HTML and CSS, made the Wordpress theme and made the site responsive. Visit Soep 't erin and have a look yourself! Another aspect of the website was that the client needed to be able to select a soup of the week and fill in the amount of soup they had already made. We did made that possible by creating a Wordpress Dashboard Widget. That way the settings would be visible the moment the client logged in. You can click the images above to have a closer look at the widget and the result the visitor sees. The launch of Soep 't erin means that two of my main projects within Designosource are pretty much finished. It's a good feeling to see the end result of your work! Let me know in the comments what you think of the website.

item.title: #HARKEN by Kaleb Nation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was introduced to Kaleb Nation because of Twilight (remember Twilight Guy? That's him!). Since then I've followed him on YouTube and other social media. Besides making video's, Kaleb's also an author. The first book he released was called Bran Hambric and the Farfield Curse. Check out his Bran Hambric series on Goodreads. I enjoyed Kaleb's Bran Hambric series, but I think that I will like his new and upcoming book even more! The book, previously known as #SecretKalebBook, is called HARKEN. You can read of summary of the book on the Harken website or you can just watch the video below and let Kaleb Nation tell you himself.

Interesting plot, huh? The cover of the book was just released, getting me even more excited for HARKEN to come out! The book will be released on January 13th, 2013. You can add the book on Goodreads.

I hope I got at least some of you interested in reading this book. I know I am. I'll try to keep you posted about the news around HARKEN! Let me know in the comments if you know Kaleb Nation. Have you read his Bran Hambric series? If yes, did you like the books? And, are you interested in reading HARKEN?

item.title: Designosource website is online!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: So it took a bit longer than we originally thought, but the time has finally come: the designosource website is online! Our website has a prehistoric theme to it. Our logo (which was designed by last years students and altered by us) is a dinosaur egg and you will discover more prehistoric illustrations throughout the website. Especially have a look at our team page, because our Illustrator expert (@GeoffVerhulst) made some really cool illustrations of the team. The website was built with the Foundation Framework (it's responsive!) and Wordpress. I did a bit of the Wordpress theming, wrote some jQuery and some other small tasks. The site isn't quite perfect yet. There a still some things that we want to improve, but this will do for now. I'd like to know your thoughts on the Designosource website, so head on over and have a look (and than come back to comment!). Feedback is much appreciated!

item.title: Survivors (TV Show Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
After the world didn't end (not that I was expecting it to), I was in the mood for something post-apocaliptic. I've always been a fan of the genre and with all the fuss about December 21st, I wanted to check out something new. So I looked around the internet and discovered the BBC series, Survivors. Survivors tells the story of a group of people who survive (duh!) a virus that kills of over 90% of the world's population. The series had two seasons, each consisting of 6 episodes, before it got cancelled. So I'm not going to go too much into the plot, because I don't want to ruin anything for anyone who might be interested in watching this. However, I do want to briefly share my thoughts, because I think it's a must-see for anyone who likes this kind of genre. I can say that the storyline is great. A diverse group of characters finds each other and they all want to survive in what's left of the world. Every character has it's own past, that you discover along the way. I was invested in the characters and I cared about their wellbeing. The acting was good, both from the main cast and secondary cast. The episodes are stand-alone with a bit of an overlap and of course the general story of the group of people trying to survive. Because the episodes are stand-alone, not every episode is as interesting. Nonetheless, I still enjoyed watching Survivors a lot. The show does end with a bit of a cliffhanger, but that didn't bother me too much, because my questions were answered. I would've loved another season of the show, but I'm also not sure what more they would have to tell. Let me know if you've watched the series as well or if you'd be interested to watch it!

IMDb | FollowMy.tv | Buy Survivors Season 1

item.title: InstaDiary: December (part 2)

Time for my second InstaDiary blog (check out the first one here). This is the second series of Instagram photos from December. First up is a random picture of a beautiful Christmas/New Years card. A picture about my first InstaDiary blog. Christmas lights in my room. Watching Survivors. Reading Life of Pi. I had to make an eBook for school and I was testing it on my Kobo. Christmas eve: I was curious about my presents. The card says "Curieuzeneuzemosterdpot" (there's no English translation for that). And a picture of the first course of dinner. Christmas decorations you may recognize from my previous blog. Has anyone noticed that that are wine glasses? The wrapping paper. Present 1: a Christmas tradition at our house. My sister and I always get a little angel statue. Present 2: a picture frame to take with me when to London (going on my internship there). Present 3: new pj's. Christmas tree without presents. Food of the dinner on Christmas day. Picture of a picture of my grandfather. It was the first Christmas without him. Dessert! Me and the Christmas tree. Already picked out some photos to put in my picture frame. Reading Life of Pi. That's my favorite quote of the book so far: "This story has a happy ending.". Me programming and watching Once Upon a Time at the same time. New slippers to keep my feet warm. Reading Life of Pi (again) with The Hobbit Soundtrack. On my way to visit my grandparents.

And finally: New Years Eve! That was December 2012 in pictures. I wish everyone a happy and healthy 2013!

item.title: 33 Books of 2012
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
About two years ago I discovered Goodreads. A great community to keep track of books you've read, are reading and want to read. Since I discovered Goodreads, I also set up a reading challenge for myself every year. In 2011 I challenged myself to read 15 books and I ended up reading 17. For 2012 I started with a goal of 20 books, but I soon increased this to 25 and later to 30 books. I ended up reading 33 books (though not everything really counts as a book in my opinion). Here are the 33 books I read in 2012. The first thing I read in 2012, was actually the 2nd Twilight graphic novel. Other books that don't really count as full books (in my opinion) that I read are: The Fantastic Flying Books of Morris Lessmore and Free Four. I also read a few web design books: Introducing HTML5, A Student's Guide to Web Design: Portfolios and Responsive Web Design. The first 'real' book of 2012 was Passion by Lauren Kate. This is the third book in the Fallen series and the worst one so far. I really didn't like it. I also finished reading A Clash of Kings (A Song of Ice and Fire #2) by George R.R. Martin. I did start this book in 2011. I took me a really long time to finish it! My favorite series of 2012 is the Divergent series. I read both books this year and I loved them both. Divergent and Insurgent by Veronica Roth are a must-read! The Free Four book I mentioned earlier is a scene from the first book, written from Four's perspective. I also finished reading the Vampire Academy series by reading "Spirit Bound" and "Last Sacrifice" by Richelle Mead. After finished the series, I couldn't help but pick up the first book in the Bloodlines series as well. Be sure to check out my review of Bloodlines. I also read:
  • Legend by Marie Lu (review on Goodreads)
  • The Fault in Our Stars by John Green (review on Goodreads)
  • Between by Jessica Warman (review on Goodreads)
  • The Titan's Curse (Percy Jackson and the Olympians #3) by Rick Riordan
  • 0.4 by Mike A. Lancaster (review on Goodreads)
  • Clockwork Prince (The Infernal Devices, #2) by Cassandra Clare (review on Goodreads)
  • Partials (Partials Sequence #1) by Dan Wells
  • The Maze Runner (Maze Runner #1) by James Dashner
  • The Hunt (The Hunt #1) by Andrew Fukuda
  • Tomorrow, When the War Began (Tomorrow #1) by John Marsden
  • The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky
  • Warm Bodies by Isaac Marion
  • The Hobbit by J.R.R. Tolkien
  • The Rise of Nine (Lorien Legacies #3) by Pittacus Lore
  • The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowling (review)
  • Uglies (Uglies #1) by Scott Westerfeld (review on Goodreads)
  • Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them by J.K. Rowling, Newt Scamander
  • Quidditch Through the Ages by J.K. Rowling, Kennilworthy Whisp
  • The Tales of Beedle the Bard by J.K. Rowling
  • City of Lost Souls (The Mortal Instruments #5) by Cassandra Clare
For 2013, I will try to read 35 books. 2013 will be a bit of a different year. I'm going to London for my internship for 3 months and I'm also graduating. So I really don't have a clue how much time I'll have to read or what my year will look like once I graduate. Did you reach your reading goal for 2012? How many books did you read? Have you read any of the book I read? And what's your goal for 2013?

item.title: Pitch Perfect (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Every since I first saw the trailer for Pitch Perfect, I was interested in seeing it. It seemed like a fun and entertaining movie. Pitch Perfect is a musical comedy about a girl, named Beca, who is coerced into joining her school's all-girls a cappella group. I had the chance of seeing Pitch Perfect and it didn't let down! Pitch Perfect is a combination of Glee (but without the cheese factor) and humor similar to Bridesmaids and Mean Girls. Only much better! The a cappella songs were surprisingly entertaining and the characters all had their own interesting qualities. One of the reasons that I really wanted to watch Pitch Perfect was the cast! Especially Anna Kendrick. I think she is an amazing actress and she proved that again in her role as Beca. This movie would be nothing, however, without Rebel Wilson. She has some of the best lines in the movie. Brittany Snow, Elizabeth Banks and the rest of the cast didn't let down either! I think Pitch Perfect is a must-see! It's funny, very entertaining, it's got great music and an amazing cast. What more could you want? Let me know in the comments below if you've seen Pitch Perfect and what your thoughts are on the movie. And if you haven't seen the movie, would you like to?

IMDb | Trailer

item.title: The Intouchables (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Intouchables is based on a true story of a French millionaire, Philippe, who is paralyzed from the neck down, after an accident. After a series of job interviews, Philippe decides to hire the one person who isn't really qualified to take care of him, but - unlike the other applicants - treats him as a human being. Driss shows Philippe a different world and helps him through the struggles of his handicap. I didn't know what to expect from this movie, but I had heard great things about it, so I gave the movie a try. And it didn't disappoint! The Intouchables is one of the best movies I have seen in a while. It may not have the most original story and it may even be a bit predictable or cliché at times, but this movie have so much heart that all that if forgiven! The story was beautiful and the humor was amazing! A typical comedy film hasn't been able to make me laugh as much as The Intouchables has. In addition to that, the music in this movie is gorgeous and the acting of François Cluzet (Philippe) and Omar Sy (Driss) was on point! I am not going to drag out this review any longer. I think it's obvious that I love this movie and that I recommend it! Have you seen The Intouchables yet? If yes, what are your thoughts? If not, would you like to see it?

item.title: Preparing for my internship in London - Part 1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Some of you may know that in a few weeks, I'll be moving to London for 3 months for my internship. Last year, I sent in my application to my school to let them know that I wanted to do an international internship and from that moment on I've been planning/preparing myself for that. Preparing for my internship has had its ups and downs and I thought it'd be interesting to share my experience so far. In this first part I'll tell you how I decided on the city and I how I found my internship.

Choosing the city

Deciding on the city was a no-brainer for me. I've pretty much been in love with London as a city, before I even visited it. In the summer of 2010, I finally went on vacation there and fell even more in love. So there's not really a very good reason for me wanting to go there, except that I really love London.

Finding an internship

When I first applied for an international internship, it didn't seem like I would've to put that much work into it. My school had a few connections with companies in London that were relevant to my studies. Because of that, I first applied to a company that the school would get me in touch with. That did not go as planned, however. Something went wrong.. I only found out about that at the beginning of the school year, somewhere in October (if I remember correctly). I kind of started to panic after that. Had I've known that this was going to happen, I would've spent all summer looking for an internship. I didn't have any choice but to start looking for an internship myself. At that time I was still in the process of renewing my portfolio site, which I then finished in quite the hurry, so that I could start sending out my applications. I then started looking around online for companies in London that might interest me. I have to say that this was harder than I thought. Most of the companies I came across of didn't even have a website that I liked. I eventually had some 20 websites saved, out of which I only applied to 5. Then there was another company that I got introduced to because a fellow student was interning there at the time. So in the end, I sent out only 6 applications. Within a week or two, I had received replies from two companies and I had an interview with them via Skype. And I can tell you: it's hard to do that via Skype. The connection wasn't ideal. With the first interview the sound didn't work properly and I had to ask multiple times to repeat the question. With the second interview, we simply lost the connection 2 or 3 times. However, both companies immediately told me that I could intern with them if I wanted to, which was great! I eventually decided to go for the first company, which is also the one that I got introduced to by my fellow student. He was able to tell me a lot about the company, which got me more interested in them. I also felt like I could learn a lot more with them (but maybe that's also because I had an insider). I don't regret my decision (yet). At the end of last month, I was in London for a day and I met part of the team that I'll be working with. Meeting them got me even more excited to start there. My mentor was telling all the things he wanted to teach me and they just seemed like really fun people. If there anything else you'd like to know about this, feel free to ask me in the comments below! The second part of this blog will be up in a few days.

item.title: Preparing for my internship in London - Part 2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Some of you may know that in a few weeks, I’ll be moving to London for 3 months for my internship. Last year, I sent in my application to my school to let them know that I wanted to do an international internship and from that moment on I’ve been planning/preparing myself for that. Preparing for my internship has had its ups and downs and I thought it’d be interesting to share my experience so far. In this second part I’ll tell you how I found a place to stay and what I would do differently.

Finding a place to stay

Finding a place to stay was also harder than I expected. I really wanted to go to London for a weekend or a day, to actually have a look at different places. I just didn't want to take the risk of agreeing on an apartment to then find out it doesn't exist or wasn't what it looked like on the pictures. This took some convincing with my parents. In the end, however, my mum and I did plan to go to London for one day. It was only then that I could really start looking for rooms and ask if I could take a look. This time I also received contact information from someone who'd stayed there the year before for his internship. This is also the room/apartment that I'll be staying in. It was the cheapest, cleanest and the most cozy. On our 'viewings-day', we ended up visiting 4 different places. Two of which we were shown by a local company that rents out rooms all over London. However, the two places they showed us were quite horrifying! Aside from the actual bedrooms, those apartments weren't clean at all! The bathrooms and toilets were... ugh.. just thinking about living there! The last place we saw was clean and decent as well. It was actually really close to my work and the centre of London, but it was really expensive and a lot smaller than the place I'll be staying in now. I will have to travel about an hour to and from work every day, but at least I'll feel comfortable at there.

What would I do different?

Let's say I'd get to do this all over again.. There are a few things that I learned along the way that I would do differently. First of all, I would not count on my school anymore. This might be a bit harsh to say, but schools offer little to no support in Belgium to their Erasmus students (or so it seems). If you ever decide to go on an international internship, I'd suggest you start looking for companies by yourself. You can apply to the ones your school has connections with as well, but just don't count on that. And if you look for companies yourself, you can find companies that you know will suit you. When it comes to finding a room in London, I wouldn't have started looking as soon as I did anymore. I planned my trip at the end of January and started searching a few weeks before that, but since I'm only moving there in March, it was a bit too soon. Don't get me wrong, I found a place to stay which I really like, but if I would've started looking about now, I would've had more options. There would've been more rooms listed that become available around the time I'm moving. If there anything else you'd like to know about this, feel free to ask me in the comments below!

item.title: Beautiful Creatures (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Beautiful Creatures tells the story of Ethan. Ethan lives in a small Southern town and when he meets Lena, he is introduced to the world of Casters. Together, they uncover dark secrets about their respective families, their history and their town. I was lucky enough to be invited to an advanced screening of the movie (the movie comes out in Belgium on February 27th) and I was pleasantly surprised by what I saw! So first things first: the movie is based on a book. Beautiful Creatures is the first book in the Caster Chronicles, written by Kami Garcia and Margaret Stohl. I read this first book way back in 2010 and I honestly don't remember much of it. I do think this is a good thing, because before watching the movie, I had heard from quite a view people that they changed a lot of things in the movie. The book did partially start coming back to me, while watching the movie. I remember that I wasn't really blown away by this book. I enjoyed it, but that was that. After seeing the movie, however, I do plan on reading the rest of the series. My expectations for Beautiful Creatures were rather low. As I thought the book was good, but not great, I wasn't really that excited for it and I honestly didn't even really think the trailers for this movie were that good. That being said: I was really surprised by how much I enjoyed watching this movie! The movie wasn't perfect, but I'd have to watch it again to really pinpoint specific scenes that I didn't like. The overall movie was really good, so I am willing to overlook those things. One of the reasons that makes this movie this good, is the acting. You can tell by watching the movie that the whole cast is really invested in it. Every single actor and actress gave it his/her all and it was a joy to see them in their characters. You can't help but fall for Alden Ehrenreich (who plays Ethan Wate). He's totally adorable, but really everyone was great. I also noticed the writing. In my opinion, it was really good. The first encounters between Ethan and Lena are great and funny moments. I even liked the way the movie ended. I've been told that the ending is very different from the book, but since I don't really remember that much of it, it didn't bother me at all. If they plan to make a movie out of the sequel, I'd definitely watch it. Have you read "Beautiful Creatures"? What did you thing of the movie (if you've seen it)? Do you plan on watching the movie? Let me know in the comments below!

IMDb | Trailer | Buy the "Beautiful Creatures" Book

item.title: Prodigy (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Prodigy by Marie Lu is the sequel to Legend. I read Legend last year in April and even though I enjoyed the story, it didn't blow me away. At first I wasn't to interested in reading the sequel, but people all over the internet were really excited for the book and some early reviews were really positive about the book. That's why I decided to give this series another try and am I glad I did, because Prodigy is a lot better than Legend! In Legend we are introduced to Day, the republic's most wanted man, and June, the republic's prodigy. In Prodigy the two join the patriots and take on a fight against the republic together. I already really like the world in Legend, but I fell in love with it while reading Prodigy. The character development in this book was also a lot better. I liked that June had doubts about what they were doing and that both June and Day were unsure about their relationship together. The only thing that I can complain about with Prodigy is the switching of perspectives. I already had a bit of a difficult time with this in Legend and it didn't get any better in Prodigy. I know that the switching is necessary in order to know the whole story, but somehow my brain was a bit confused from time to time. That doesn't take away, however, that Prodigy is absolutely amazing. I was engaged the whole time and that ending was just... wow! After reading Prodigy, I also read the little novella "Life Before Legend", which includes two stories: one of Day and one of June from when they were 12 years old. The stories were a nice addition to the series. I do recommend you read both Legend and Prodigy before reading the novella. You'll enjoy it more if you do. I can really recommend the Legend series and I look forward to the next book in the series! Have you read Legend/Prodigy? What did you think about them? Are you interested in reading the series? Let me know!

item.title: It's time for a little adventure!

Let's do this thing! :D And in case you're wondering about the picture: I couldn't help but think about Bilbo Baggins going on his adventure while writing this post, so I thought it was a fitting illustration to the blog :).

item.title: First week in London, first week at the internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Last saturday I arrived in London to start my next adventure: an international internship! This first week was already great: fun projects, a lot to look forward to and my first lesson in SEO. Before getting into what my week was like, I would like to apologize for the lack of blogs. I know it's been a week already, but after work I don't really have to time to write blogs. I'll try to blog more often and maybe write some blogs in advance, but I'm quite busy now, so I don't know if I can. Sorry!

Weekend of my arrival

Enough of that, let's get into my week! So, I travelled to London on March 2nd by Eurostar. I arrived in London at around 10am (London time) and about an hour later I arrived at the apartment. I met my flatmates: B. and her boyfriend and M. After I unpacked and had my first English omelet, B. and her boyfriend showed me the neighborhood. The first day was mainly getting things arranged for the rest of my stay. On the second day I decided to do the route from my apartment to my internship. After I did that, I ended up in the Westfield shopping centre of Shepherd's Bush. I just thought I'd have a look around, not knowing how huge that place is! I didn't buy anything, but there was plenty of temptation though!

Week 1 at the internship

On Monday, I started my internship! I'm doing my internship at Go Up. They are one of the top SEO agencies in London. I'll mostly be doing development work for them, but there's more. I got the news that I'll also get to do a bit of design work. Once I've finished a couple of development projects, they'll give me a project that I'll get to do from start to finish. Which means I'll do the design, development and SEO. This week I finished one project and started a second one. I've also had my first lesson in SEO (or as they like to call it: Inbound Marketing). Once I get the green light from them, I'll share the projects I've worked on with you. So far, I'm really enjoying myself. The internship is great, the colleagues are fun and I look forward to what's to come! Let me know how your week was! And if you have any tips of what I should do/see in London!

item.title: An Afternoon in Greenwich

I went there on foot, which means that I went trough the Greenwich Foot Tunnel. The first thing I saw when I arrived in Greenwich was the Cutty Sark Clipper Ship. After taking a few pictures of the ship and being distracted by a Waterstones bookshop, I went to the Greenwich Market and later to the park. Greenwich is a beautiful place and I'll definitely go back once the weather is better so that the view is even more beautiful! But for now, here are some pictures of my afternoon there..

item.title: Week 2 at the Internship: More Development and More SEO
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Aside from being completely uninspired about what to name these blog posts, I'm having a lot of fun here in London and at my internship. I'm afraid that I'll be repeating myself every single week, but the fact is that the work is fun and the colleagues are really nice people! I'm starting to settle into the new routine, the long hours, the commuting and somewhat taking care of myself.

Week 2 at the internship

This week I mostly worked on two development projects. The first one is a website for a Chandelier Designer. I started working on this website last week and it's nearly finished. This website has been a bit of a technical challenge for me, but seeing it come together is really fulfilling. The second project is for a party organisation. So far I only had to put together a couple of pages so that they could put the site live already and add additional pages later on. I finished this one this week and you can watch it live here. The website I developed last week also went live: have a look at the London's Man and Van website. On thursday, I spent most of my day doing some SEO work. In the morning I got an introduction to On-Site Optimisation, which basically means they explained to me what codes to put where and such. In the afternoon, I applied that knowledge to a website.

Living "on my own"

Technically I'm not living on my own, because I have two flatmates, but I do have to cook, go to the supermarket and all those things. So far there are two things that I really miss: decent bread and my mum's cooking! Bakeries in London are quite expensive and so only bread I can get here is in the supermarket and that bread is more meant for making toast than making sandwiched. When it comes to cooking I can say that I'm not the best cook (yet). First of all, I think it's very hard to decide what I want to eat and than cooking it goes rather slow. What I've made so far has been quite successful, but I have kept my meals quite basic. However, I have discovered that the supermarkets here are well equipped for the lazy, busy and inexperienced cook. You can find unions that are already chopped, meat for bolognese sauce that already have some vegetables in it and portions of fruit that's already been sliced and peeled. I do try to cook most things fresh, though!

Next week

The coming week will be a bit different and exciting because Go Up is moving offices. So far we've been working in the flat of one of the bosses. This does mean that I'll have to take a different route to work, which is something new I'll have to get used to. Aside from that I've got a fun project that I'll start on Monday. All I can/will say for now is that I'll have to create a logo and a couple of banners. That's it for now! Have a good weekend everyone!
