item.title: Week 3 at the Internship was all about Designing!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
These past 3 weeks have passed so quickly! I can't believe week 3 is already over. I think this week might have been the best week I've had here so far. I was quite an exciting week as well, because Go Up moved offices and I got to do a lot of design work.

The new office

Week 3 started off a bit unusual, because on Monday I had to work from home. As I mentioned last week, Go Up moved offices! This was quite exciting since we were working in Ed's house before the move. While the bosses were moving to the new office and putting together new desks from IKEA, the designer, developer and I were working from our homes. On Tuesday we started working at the new office and it's an amazing place! They've put fake grass on the floor, there's a small ping pong table (I'll need to improve my ping pong skills) and a football lying around. Here are a few pictures I took (please ignore the mess):

Commuting to the new office

Normally I'd say stories about commuting aren't that interesting, but I've had quite an interesting week on this subject. If you follow me on Twitter then you may have read my tweet saying that I couldn't try out the new route to work because part of the Circle line was closed for maintenance. That's why I left half an hour earlier than usual for work, just to be sure. I had/have a few options to get to the new office. Option 1 requires only one change, but that would mean that most of my journey would be on the Circle line and this line has a reputation for being quite slow. Option 2 is changing twice, but being on a fast line (the Jubilee line) for most of my journey. On Tuesday morning I tried out option 1. I left early and that was a good thing too! As you also may have read on Twitter, I got stuck on the DLR. The train before us had some problems and we were stuck between two stations for at least 15 minutes. Then I needed to change at the Circle line, which was a bit confusing as well, but I found my way. Unfortunately, the Circle line is indeed very very slow! I arrived at work 10 minutes late.. In the evening I tried option 2 with a colleague who lives in the same area, but I forgot to check the time so I didn't really know if that was a good option. The next morning I tried option 1 again, to see how it would go without delays but it took me an hour and a half, so that option was officially of the table. I've been using option 2 ever since. It's the fastest way (about on hour). The Jubilee line is really busy but at least it's fast.

Quick introduction of the Go Up team

A friend pointed out to me that I haven't really said much about Go Up and even though this post is quite long already, I just want to quickly introduce the Go Up team. Go Up is a team of 5 people that work at the office every day. They do have a few other people who often work for them, but don't come into the office. They also often reinforce their team with interns. The company sort of has 3 bosses: Ed, Tom and Simon. Ed and Tom founded Go Up together and Simon joined the team later on. Ed is the one who's been teaching me all the SEO stuff and he's also an actor. Then there's one designer, Bahador "Botte" (he's from Iran) and one developer, Mircea (he's from Romania). Mircea is my mentor, since I'm officially working as a development intern, but I've been working really close with Botte as well since I did a lot of design work this week. And of course I can't forget Winston, the dog! The whole team is very young and a lot of fun. The oldest person is 27 and the youngest 23 (not counting me). This week a new intern joined the team: Natalia. She's from Poland and she's here as a design intern.

The work of week 3

Like I've said a few times already: I've been designing this week and it was a lot of fun! My first assignment was to design a logo, which I was a bit nervous about. I haven't designed that many logos yet, but it turned out quite well. I had to design a banner for them as well, which I did once the logo was approved. I'll explain more about the project when I'm allowed to show the work I've done. Up next was a homepage concept for EPoS SPA. I made another homepage concept for a different company, but I will spare you their current website because it's horrendous! I also got to design a landing page and started on a homepage design for SEO Courses and Training. I think that was all for this week. I did a bit a development work in between. I had to take over from Mircea for a few hours on Friday because he had an upcoming deadline but was needed somewhere else. No SEO this week, because Ed was away on a skiing holiday (he sneaked out of the moving as well!). Like I said: it was a great week. Now that I'm listing everything it looks like I got a lot of work done this week! I also got to know the team a lot better this week, which is always nice. Sorry if you think this posts was too long, but there was a lot to tell and I'm sure I still forgot to mention a few things. Let me know if there's anything particular you want to know about my stay here or about my internship, because I feel like I'm just rambling on and on :P.

item.title: First Month at the Internship is already over!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In a few days time I'll officially be in London for a month, but since it's Easter weekend now, my first month at Go Up is already over! Time flies when you're having fun. This week was another combination of different kinds of work, but this time it appears the long hours were weighing on me, because I was really tired! It was another fun week, nonetheless.

SEO, Design, Development and Writing

This week Ed was back, which meant that I had to do some SEO again this week. I did some Keyword Research for another client. No SEO lesson this week, though, because Ed had some work to catch up on since he was gone for a week. What else did I do? I finished the banners for the client I mentioned last week. I worked some more on the homepage design for SEO Courses and Training. I quickly helped Botte, the designer, out by designing some inner pages and yesterday I adjusted a design. The design was made by someone we don't know, but the client came to Go Up and allowed us to make some changes to the design (and that was necessary). It was a bit of a pain to do, because I didn't quite agree with the design that was made at all. There were just too many thing wrong with it. Anyway, I made it as good as I could. I did a bit of development this week, but not a lot. I started building a new website and I made some tweaks to an existing one. Something completely new this week was that I had to write an article! To help out with SEO, Go Up maintains blogs related to the businesses of their clients and they had to write a bunch of them yesterday about Data Centres. I had to write one as well. It took a while to find my subject, but once I had that the writing went quite smoothly. Simon said he was impressed that Natalia (the other intern) and me were able to write so well, while English is not even our native language. Nice!

Random events at the office

With Ed being back, he insisted on getting some things in order for the new office, which caused quite a few things to happened this week. First of all Ed wanted to assemble a filing cabinet they bought, but he soon discovered that some things were missing (oh, IKEA!). He then spend most of his day trying to get IKEA to send them the missing parts. While waiting he was getting some framed posters ready to be put up on the wall. For some reason he needed superglue to do this and while opening the tube, he managed to get some superglue into his eye! Luckily someone in the team reacted quite fast and got some eye drops in his eye. He ended up going to the hospital and he's fine now. The next day IKEA delivered a new filing cabinet which then missed a few holes, but Ed ended up drilling them himself. It still took forever to get the thing together, though! We also put up the posters. The office is starting to look more and more like it should. Next week they are going to get the little kitchen ready. A fun, but short week.. Also quite a short blog compared to last week. Happy Easter everyone!

item.title: Week 5 at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My second month at Go Up started this week. Monday was a bank holiday and so I had that day off. On Tuesday, we started working again and this week has been a bit more stressful for me. As I mentioned in my previous blog, I had to make some adjustments to an existing design. This project continued this past week and was the reason for the stress.

The work of Week 5

There's a bit of pressure on the project to get it finished and online as soon as possible. So on Tuesday, I spent all day making further adjustments to the design, sending it to the client, waiting for feedback, making adjustments based on the feedback and so on and so on. That day was quite exhausting for me, because every single time I needed to wait on feedback, I'd work on a different project. But once I received feedback on the design, I'd drop what I was doing and get back on editing the design. I discovered that it's quite hard to get back into a project when you're switching every hour or two. Luckily, the days after, I split up my day, working on one project in the morning and the other in the afternoon. That didn't take the stress away however, because aside from designing that one project, I also need to build it. I did, however, ask them to not give me any other projects until this one is done, so that I can put all my focus on that one and don't have to stress about other deadlines. I am aware of the fact that my bosses wouldn't be mad at me if it'd take me a day longer to build it than planned, but the perfectionist in me wants to do a good job, no matter what. With that comes stress, over which I have no control. I am taking this as a lesson though, as I'm sure this won't be the only time I need to work with a bit of pressure. I worked on this "stress" project for most of the week, as well as developing another website. I also received the news that a design I made, was chosen by the client (both I and the other intern made a design), which is always nice! I also finished a project, which you can now find in my portfolio.

Mobile Money Africa Awards 2013

Some of you may have already noticed that on Friday, I added a new project to my portfolio: Mobile Money Africa Awards 2013. I mentioned in an earlier blog that I was designing a logo and banners. This project is now finished, so I can tell you all about it! The reason that I got this project was so that I can hand this in as a school assignment as well. For my Interactive Marketing class, the students were asked to design a banner and a landing page (if I'm correct?). I missed the briefing for that assignment and I emailed the teacher to ask for more information. He then told me that, because I'm in London, I'd be allowed to make the assignment as part of my internship. He said that I could hand in either a landing page or banners, that I made during my internship. I informed the Go Up team about this and in a matter of hours they gave me this project. I was asked to design a logo for the awards and design several banners. Have a look on the MMAA project page to see how it turned out. [gallery link="file" ids="3391,3392,3393"] Feel free to let me know what you think of the MMAA logo and banners I designed. Have a great Sunday!

item.title: Week 6 at the Internship: Halfway through!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The end of Week 6 means that I'm already halfway through my time here. Only 1,5 month to go! I completed the "stress"-project and worked on a few other things. This week was also the first week where I truly realised how much I actually miss my family.

Finishing the "Stress"-Project

On Monday I jumped right back into that one project that was causing me stress last week. Thanks to a nice weekend, I wasn't stressed for it anymore, but I was more than glad to finished the project. The biggest coding had already been done and so Monday and Tuesday were mostly working out some details and creating the blog page for the website. The website went live on Wednesday and so I guess I can show it to you. Click here to see the "stress"-project website. I once again want to point out that I just made changes to an existing design and I would've done quite a number of things differently. However, due to the urgency of this project and the limited amount of resources, this is the result. It also might not look so great, depending on your screen size. On Thursday the client came in and I gave him a quick Wordpress lesson on how to edit and create posts and pages and how to use certain plugins that were used for his website. Afterwards Tom (who was overseeing the project) came to thank me for doing this project from start to finish and making it a smooth process of communicating with the client and getting the website online so fast (I just checked and it took 8 work days to finish this project). Looking back on it now, I am quite proud of the work I did for this project, but because of the amount of stress it caused me, I am more than happy that it's over.

Other Work This Week

What else did I do this week? Well, I finished developing another website that I had started building last week. The client has yet to confirm it, however, so I can't show it to you just yet. I also started building a blog for an existing Go Up client and I finally had another SEO lesson with Ed. Among other things we talked about the Syndication/Source Tag, Google Parameter Blocking and Link Building. If all goes as planned, next week should be about writing content, which I'll get an assignment for. This should be challenging! I also did some design work this week, but half a day of that turned out to be a bit of a waste of time, due to miscommunication with the client. I won't go into any further details. However, I did enjoy the designing, but it's a bit frustrating to find out it was a waste of time. I have another design project which I tried to work on on Thursday and Friday, but that didn't go so well. On Thursday my mind was too pre-occupied to try and be creative and on Friday I was simply too tired.

Worrying About Home

I'll only go into this quite briefly as it is quite personal, but it was a big part of this week so I thought I'd mention it. On Thursday, my mum was having a surgery and I was quite worried about her. I knew about the surgery before I left for London and I knew it wasn't that big of a procedure, but not being able to be with her and my family freaked me out a bit. I spent most of that day worrying about her, waiting the hear news. My mum is OK (as everyone kept telling me while I was worrying) and the surgery went well. She's back home now and just needs a lot of rest in order to recover. This event did make me realise that I do miss my family. So far it seems that I just hadn't had time to miss them, but this week I thought about them a lot. I'm glad my parents are visiting in two weeks. I'll be good to see them in the flesh and not just through Skype. Luckily, I went to a concert on Thursday evening, which allowed me to let go of the things going on at home and relax! The concert was of Imagine Dragons and it was amazing! Be sure to have a look at my Instagram for a few pictures. The concert totally cheered me up again and well, the band is just great live! Fun fun fun! That's all for this week! How was your week?

item.title: Week 7 at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This week was another combination of both design and development. No SEO lessons this week, because Ed was ill on the day(s) he was supposed to teach me about writing content. I however did manage to find some inspiration and made some progress on a project that I was stuck on last week. I also had a few boring jobs that needed to be done and I started building the new Go Up website!

The Fun Stuff

This week wasn't quite as eventful as last week (which I didn't mind). My two hightlights of the week were finally making progress on the design for SEO Courses and Training and starting to build the Go Up website. Last week was a bit of a struggle for the SEO website, because I just didn't know what to do with the design. On Monday, however, I started over and finally managed to make something that I actually liked. With the help of Botte, Go Up's Creative Director, I managed to create a design that I am quite proud of. Hopefully it won't take too long before I can show the result to you. Go Up is working on a new website and since the homepage design was already finished, I was asked to start building it! I think the new design is great and building it has been quite fun so far. Especially the slider, which has some animations in it. I'll let you know when the website is live (it might take a bit of time though).

The Boring Stuff

Sometimes certain things need to be done that aren't necessarily fun or interesting to do. I had two little assignments this week that might be considered quite boring. The first was adding products and uploading pictures to a client's website. Normally I would hate this kind of task, because it's very repetitive and mind numbing. This time, however, I didn't mind turning my brain of for an hour. The second one was fixing some mistakes made in a website that was build by a previous intern at Go Up. The intern didn't quite bother to follow the design so much and that needed to be fixed. So I sat down with Botte and we went through the designs he made and the website that was build. Making these changes was a bit of a pain, because the website wasn't really build in the right way (in my opinion). Images were used, where it'd be better to use text, etc. It went alright though and I didn't mind it that much once I started working on it. Not much to tell this week, but not every week has to be eventful :). Let me know what boring tasks you've had to do at work!

item.title: Warner Bros. Studio Tour London: The Making of Harry Potter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This past Sunday the day was finally there: I was going to the Harry Potter Studio Tour in London! As a massive Potterhead, I was really looking forward to seeing all of the sets, costumes, etc. and experience the world of Harry Potter myself. Here's what the tour was like.. At the beginning of the tour everyone gathered in this room where someone briefly gave us some guidelines and kept us busy until it was time for us to start the tour. The reason I am mentioning this part of the tour is because they showed a short video where producer David Heyman explains how he was introduced to Harry Potter. At the end of the video they showed some footage from different premieres, including the premiere I attended. As it turn out I (and my friends) are in that video, which I think is pretty cool! After this, we entered a small cinema room where we were shown an introduction video to the tour. They showed some clips from the movies and some behind-the-scenes footage. Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson and Rupert Grint then introduced the tour (on the video of course). As the video ended, the screen went up and there it was: the door to the Great Hall! I have to admit that going into the Great Hall wasn't as magical as I imagined. Yes, the set is absolutely beautiful, but without the magical ceiling it's just not the same. The rest of the tour was split up in different sections. The first were all the indoor sets: the Gryffindor Common Room, Dumbledore's Office, the Weasley hour and a lot of other props from the movies. The second part was outdoors were you could see Private Drive number 4, The Knight Bus and more. The third part was the creature shop. I really enjoyed walking through these first three parts, looking at all of the sets in detail, the graphic design that was created for the movies and the creation of the creatures. The last two parts of the tour, however, were my absolute favorite. Part four of the tour was Diagon Alley and it was - in my opinion - the most magical part of the tour. When I turned that corner and entered the set it felt as if I had stepped right into the movie. It was amazing and so beautiful! The next best thing was the model room were I was amazed by the miniature version of Hogwarts! The last room before you enter the shop is the inside of Ollivanders Wand Shop, where the names of everyone who worked on the Harry Potter movies were written on the wand boxed. I think it took us about three hours to get through the whole tour and it was totally worth its money! I can recommend it to every Potterhead out there. It's just a must-see! Have you ever been to the Harry Potter Studio Tour? If yes, what did you think? If no, do you plan on going? Pictures by Joyce Van Herck & Zosja van Sonsbeek

item.title: Week 8 at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It's nearly been two months now and I am still enjoying the internship to the fullest! I have been very tired lately, though, but I suppose that's not unusual since I'm not used to working so much! Whenever I am writing these blogs, I have a hard time remembering all the work I've done for the past week and since this week was a rather calm one it seems as if I've done nothing at all.

The Work in Week 8

At the beginning of the week I finished the changes to the "boring" assignment I mentioned last week. I also continued building the homepage for the new Go Up website. A client also sent me some feedback on his website. I immediately made the changes he requested (mostly fixed for IE) and now I am waiting for the client to confirm this. Once he does this, I can show you the website. This week I also started building a new website, which will require an e-commerce plugin. So far I've mostly worked on the homepage and the regular pages, but I've started figuring out the plugin a bit as well. The only design work of this week (for so far as I can remember anyway) was for an existing website. The client requested a web shop, which I got to design. It's a fairly simple design, but it was a nice change from the development work. Mircea, the developer, and I were also asked by the rest of the team to give a presentation about what exactly it is we do when building websites. I've also been preparing a bit for this during the week. I'll be talking about HTML, CSS, JavaScript/jQuery and Responsive Web Design. Mircea will cover servers, MySQL and other techie stuff.

Other news

I've got quite a few busy weekends coming up! Right now my parents are in London with friends and I'll be spending the weekend with them. Seeing my parents yesterday and being able to hug them was great! I can't wait for the rest of the weekend! Next week my sister will come for a visit and over the next few weekends some other friends might come over for a visit as well. I'm excited! Short blog this week, but that's mostly because I don't have much time since my parents are visiting.

item.title: InstaDiary: April 2013
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Here's what happened during my second month in London! The new season of Game of Thrones started at the beginning of the month (well, at the end of last month really) and I was halfway through the 3rd book when the season started. / Monday April 1st was a Bank Holiday and so I decided to go on a walk through London. The next 3 pictures are of that walk: 2 pictures at the Millennium Bridge and one of an Underground sign in Canary Warf. / A few day later we had a fire drill (or so we thought). 3 fire trucks showed up and I turned out that it wasn't a drill. I still don't know what was wrong though, because the building wasn't on fire. / The whole building was outside (it was snowing) and I was quite surprised about the amount of people that apparently work there. / Celebrating my flatmate's birthday. / At the Canada Water Library. It's a beautiful building! 3 more pictures at Canada Water. / Winston met a lady version of himself. Someone in the building we work came to say hi and introduce the dogs to each other. Cuteness overload! / My HARKEN prize pack arrived! / In the queue for the Imagine Dragons concert. / First support act: Eliza and the Bear. They were really good! / Imagine Dragons was amazing! During Radioactive. The crowd went wild. / I put up my HARKEN poster. I've had to move it to my closet door though, because it didn't stick on the wall. / Beautiful morning! / Great book quote. / Bought 4 books and Game of Thrones (season 1 + 2) on DVD. / Preview of the website I was designing. / Another sunny morning! / Skyping with the Designosource team back home. The London Marathon passed by my flat. / The brave people running the marathon. / Getting on the Harry Potter Shuttle Bus. / Arrived at Leavesden Studios. / Ticket to the Harry Potter Studio Tour. / Tried Butterbeer. I didn't really like it. / Winston sleeping. / Another concert: this was the support act. Went to the OneRepublic concert in London. It was a fun show! And it ended with confetti :). / Go Up ordered new chairs and the guys were quite excited when they arrived. / Go Up cake! It was a gift from Tom's girlfriend, Lottie. / It was delicious! / At Greenwich again, this time I was there with my parents. I ate this massive burger! / Received this wooden iPhone case from my parents. / At Camden with my parents. / This morning, taking the bus to work, due to delays on the Circle line. That's all for this month! Only one more month left in London.. Bring it on!

item.title: Week 9 at the Internship was a Short One
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Week 9 started out great. Seeing my parents and their friends last weekend, really gave me the boost that I needed and Monday was an amazing day. This didn't last, unfortunately, as the tiredness finally took its toll: I fell ill.

The Work of Week 9

Throughout the week, I mostly worked on the same project. It's the e-commerce project I mentioned last week. The site is built in Wordpress and so I decided to use the WP e-Commerce plugin to create the shop. Since I've never really used an e-commerce plugin before, implementing this went rather slow. I figured it out in the end though and most of it is done. Monday was the best day of the whole week. I felt so happy and energetic and the day just flew by. Tuesday was a bit less fun, however. I ended up having a (surprise) meeting with the client of the e-commerce website I'm working on. I already felt quite annoyed that I didn't know, because I was unable to prepare, but I guess this was a good exercise, as I'm sure something similar will happen in the future. The main reason that this meeting sort of ruined my day, is because the client mentioned quite a few things that I should've known a lot sooner (not now, in the middle of the building process). At Go Up, the designer and builder of a project don't always have a meeting with the client before starting on the project. So far this hasn't been a problem for me at all, since Ed, Tom or Simon would always give me a proper brief. This time it seems like some questions might not have been asked. I did mention this to Ed the next day. Wednesday was quite a fun and exciting day as well. That day a new intern started: Emily. She will be doing editorial/copywriting work. Another interesting experience for me that day was that I gave the whole Go Up team a basic lesson in HTML, CSS, JavaScript/jQuery and Responsive Web Design. As I mentioned last week, the team asked for this because, before, they didn't understand anything of what developers do. I have to say it went quite well and they did say I did a good job! It was a bit hard sometimes to explain everything. On the one hand because I'm so familiar with it and on the other hand because I had to explain it to people who have a limited technical knowledge. It was really fun to do however! There wasn't time for Mircea's part of the presentation, so hopefully we'll get to that next week.

Getting sick.. and my sister visiting

It was bound to happen to happen sometime, and this week was that time: I fell ill. As much fun as my weekend with my parents and their friends was, it was also a very tiring one. I had been tired for some time before already and apparently my body couldn't fight it anymore. On Wednesday my throat started to bug me and I was losing my voice a bit. By the end of the day, I wasn't feeling that great, but I decided to meet up with a friend and her boyfriend anyway. I assumed I was just getting a cold. So that evening, I went to see Iron Man 3. I loved the movie, but by the end I was feeling miserable. Thursday morning, I was feeling ok, so I decided to go to work. I don't tend to stay home when I have a cold and I wasn't going to change that now. It turns out that this might have been the worst cold I've ever had. Ed ordered me to go home after I'd finished one assignment. I went home Thursday afternoon and I stayed home on Friday as well. My sister was coming to London later that day and I wanted to be able to show her around London. I also really didn't feel like sitting in front of a computer all day. I simply needed to rest! Friday was quite a miserable day as well. I felt like my head was going to explode at times. I pulled through though and picked up my sister from the station at 4. I even ended up going to the Go Up office with her to meet everyone and we hung around for a bit. I was incredibly happy to go to bed that night and luckily, this morning, I was feeling so much better! Since it was my sister's first time in London, we went to Westminster station to see the Big Ben, Houses of Parliament, The London Eye and so on. Unfortunately, it started raining around noon and - to my sister's joy - I took her to Westfield in Shepherd's Bush (the largest shopping centre in London). We had a great first day together and we have 2 more days to go since Monday is a bank holiday! Have a good weekend everyone!

item.title: Week 10 at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Week 10 was an amazing week. The past few weeks had been a bit slow and I worked on the same projects a lot, but week 10 was completely different. It was a very busy week with deadlines coming closer and because of that, I got to work on all kinds of different projects. I had a blast doing it!

The Work of Week 10

To my own surprise, the massive workload of week 10 didn't cause me stress.. No, I actually enjoyed it and this has been the best week I've had in a while. Monday was a Bank Holiday and at the end of last week I was ill, so suddenly the deadline for my e-commerce project was very close. I managed to finish the work that I was able to do on my own, but the problem was that I needed Mircea to help me make some adjustments to the plugin we were using. The client wanted a pre order system, which isn't in the WP e-Commerce plugin. Mircea was busy as well, so he only found time later in the week to help me out with that. The website is close to being finished. I think it will go live at the beginning of next week. This week a website I built finally went live. I started building this website in the first week of my internship. The build was finished a long time ago, but it took the client quite a while to deliver all the products for the website. So go have a look! I have to admit that I'm not the biggest fan of the design and it was quite a pain to build as well, but I am more than happy to finally see this website live! On Tuesday, I had to help Mircea out with one of the projects he was supposed to build. He had a lot of work on his plate and so I took over one of his project for a day. I finished building the website's homepage and basic pages. I somehow also managed to find time to start building a blog for a client, which you can see here. I also had some Onsite Optimisation work this week (SEO stuff). I had done the onsite for the same client before, but they completely changed their website and added a bunch of new pages. So, Ed did some Keyword Research for the new pages, and I did the onsite for them. On Thursday and Friday I found a bit of spare time to continue building the new Go Up website. This lovely week ended with a fun Friday evening. Sebastian - a previous Go Up intern and fellow student at my school - came by for a visit. A group of us went out, had pizza and a few drinks. Have a good Sunday everyone!

item.title: Week 11 at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Week 11 was less busy then last week, or at least for me. I started working on a new project that ended up being my main priority of the week. I also realised that I only have two more weeks left!

The Work of Week 11

On Monday I started working on a project that was - again - quite urgent. I had to start building a website for a logo design company. The website wasn't designed by Go Up, but it's an overall simple website. The only difficult thing was the order form and this is also the reason why the website wasn't completely built by the end of the week. Everything aside from the order form has been built. I do think that the client will ask for some more changes after the site goes live. During the build process he kept emailing me for changes he wanted to the design. We then had to ask him wait with emailing changes, if he wanted the website to be finished by Friday. For the order form the client wanted the user to have 3 different payment options: by card (where you fill in your details within the website), PayPal and by phone. We tried to convince him to just use PayPal, but he insisted on having these 3 options there. We then decided to purchase a plugin that would make this a lot easier. Unfortunately, I was unable to start working on this before the end of my week. I have today (Friday) off, because friends from Belgium are visiting. The e-commerce website I've been working on for the past few weeks still isn't live. I had to pass the project along to Mircea, because we had to make quite a few changes to the WP e-Commerce plugin that I couldn't do on my own. There also wasn't time to let me figure it out by myself.

The Final Two Weeks

I cannot believe that I have only two more weeks left at Go Up. The team was quite surprised as well. Simon really wants me to finish the design for SEO Courses and Training before I leave, and Ed asked me yesterday to spend next week working only on the Go Up website. Hopefully I'll be able to build most or everything of the new website! I also hope that I'll find time to finished the SEO Courses and Training design. Have a lovely weekend everyone! I look forward to spending mine with some friends from school!

item.title: Week 12 at the Internship: the End is Near!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This past week was my second to last week here in London. This week was filled with work for both my internship and for school. I had meetings with clients, worked on several websites (including the new Go Up website) and already had to say goodbye to one person in the office.

The Work of Week 12

The two projects that I've been working on for the past few weeks are live! Both the e-Commerce website and the Logo Design website are up and running. Both website still need a bit of work, but it's nothing too major, so we put them online. I also met with both of those clients and gave them a little lesson on how to use Wordpress to edit their website. When I wasn't making adjustments to those two websites, I worked on the new Go Up website! I've caught up with Botte on what he's designed so far. Hopefully the website will go live before I return to Belgium!

School Work

This week was more busy outside of the internship, due to upcoming deadlines for school. I had a paper due and unfortunately, I had to spend a few evenings after work writing it. Then on Thursday, I had my weekly meetings with the Designosource team. Aside from the morning meeting, pretty much the whole day was filled with other meetings for the different projects. Our final presentation is coming up and we're all preparing for it. We also have our final projects to finish and reports to write.

The End is Near

Next week is my final week at Go Up. It's only a four day week, because Monday is a Bank Holiday. I already had to say my first goodbye on Thursday, because Tom left on holiday. He thanked me for the work I've done and said that I did a really good job. Next week will be filled with goodbyes and wrapping up my different projects. I have mixed feelings about it! I really look forward to seeing my family and friends again, but I will miss the Go Up team and London so much!

item.title: Last Week at the Internship
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Monday was a Bank Holiday so, unfortunately, my last week at Go Up was a rather short one. It was a week filled with thinking about the future, having mixed feelings about going home and saying goodbyes.

The Work of Week 13

This last week wasn't busy for me at all. I didn't take on any new projects and it was all about wrapping things up. My main focus was on the Go Up website. I managed to complete most of the build, but unfortunately there's still much more to do and so it's not live just yet. Aside from that, I did a few more little things for EPoS SPA and UK Logo Design. On Friday, I emailed both of these clients to let them know that it was the last day of my internship. Both sent me some beautiful replies back with a lot of praise for my work and wishing me good luck. Some smaller jobs I did was copy a blog from Posterous to Wordpress and I again took over a project that Mircea had to build for a few hours, so that he could do other things.

The End

That's it. Three months in London, three months at Go Up. All done! I've had the time of my live. I learned a lot, not only about design, development and SEO, but also about myself. Like I said, this past week also got my thinking about my future a lot. This internship made it clear to me that I want to start working in design and development. I had always said that I would want to keep on studying, but I can do that while working as well. Right now I don't know what the future will hold, but I'll have to decide whether or not to return to London and I'll have to start applying for jobs. I don't quite realise that it's all over yet. I said goodbye to everyone and I know that I will miss everyone I met here, but it hasn't sunk in just yet. I do look forward to going home however and seeing my family and friends again. Thanks to those who've been reading my blogs for the past three months! Once I get back home, I'm planning to post some blogs about the things I did in my spare time here in London. So look forward to that!

item.title: The Golden Lily (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I figured since I reviewed Bloodlines, that I should review its sequel The Golden Lily as well. The Golden Lily is the second book in the Bloodlines series by Richelle Mead. I love Richelle Mead's writing, but The Golden Lily just wasn't as great as her other books. The Golden Lily continues the story of alchemist Sydney and her friends. This time she's not just doing her job, but she's experiencing a relationship and dating for the first time. By reading this book, I realised that, in most of Mead's books, nothing really happens until the last 100 pages. So far this isn't something that bothered me, but in this book it was quite obvious and I was just waiting for something to happen. In this book Sydney starts dating this new character. I never liked him and from there first date, it was too obvious that Sydney was actually falling for someone else. I was never really invested in their relationship, so reading about their dates wasn't exactly the most interesting for me. The last hundred pages were the most interesting to read, but in a way, a bit too predictable. Especially the ending. I loved the final chapter, but I could see it coming from a mile away. Overall I really enjoyed reading this book. As every book by Richelle Mead, it was a very quick read, which was exactly what I needed. I don't think The Golden Lily is as good as her previous books, though. I know this review comes across a bit negative, but even if there's something I don't like, I can't help but enjoy books by Richelle Mead. The book met my expectations and it was exactly the kind of book I needed after reading A Storm of Swords. That's why I gave this book 4 out of 5 stars. Have you read The Golden Lily? Do you agree with me or do you have a different opion? If you haven't read it, do you plan to?

Buy The Golden Lily | Goodreads

item.title: When In London: Films Watched
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
During my 3 months in London, I paid a few visits to the cinema. I was fascinated by Side Effects, let down by The Host, couldn't stop laughing during Iron Man 3 and discovered the world of Stark Trek Into Darkness.

Side Effects

Side Effects is a movie about a women who is suffering from side effects from an antidepressant drug. This movie is quite artistic and definitely fascinating. It's a movie that does require your attention, however, and even then it was still very confusing. I don't think this movie is for everyone, but I actually managed to enjoy it. For as far as I can remember, I also really liked the visuals of the movie. I probably wouldn't have watched this movie, if it wasn't for the friend I went with, but I'm glad that I did see it.

IMDb | Watch the Trailer

The Host

In The Host, earth has been taken over by aliens, invading human bodies. It's based on a book by Stephenie Meyer. I absolutely love the book and I was excited for the movie, but unfortunately, it was a let down. The movie had me laughing a few times at moments that were supposed to be serious or romantic. They completely ruined the love story of the book and put too much focus on it. Don't get me wrong, I didn't completely dislike the movie, but there were just too many things that seemed off. There was hardly any character development, Ian fell in love from one second to the next, ... . It's really too bad, because this movie could've been amazing. I will watch it again some time in the future. Just to have another look at it.

IMDb | Watch the Trailer

Iron Man 3

What to say about Iron Man 3? The whole movie can be summarized by saying "awesome and hilarious"! I had an absolute blast watching Iron Man 3! The movie was action packed and full of humor that had me laughing pretty much the whole way through. The best Iron Man film so far and I really recommend watching it (if you haven't already).

IMDb | Watch the Trailer

Stark Trek Into Darkness

Until the release of this movie, I wasn't really familiar with the world of Star Trek. I haven't watch the tv show and I had only watched the 2009 Star Trek movie, the day before I went to see Star Trek Into Darkness. I enjoyed both Star Trek and Stark Trek Into Darkness a lot! It wasn't anything too special, but Star Trek Into Darkness was a visually beautiful film and I really enjoyed watching it.

IMDb | Watch the Trailer

Have you watched any of these movies? Did you like them? Which ones do you plan on seeing?

item.title: When In London: Books Bought
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Three months in London meant three months of being able to walk into bookstores like Waterstones and Foyles and be tempted by all the books that are rather hard to find in Belgium. Sure you can buy books online, but walking around in a bookstore is that much more fun. And as you can see, I went home with quite a few books.. Oops!

Inside HBO's Game of Thrones

Inside HBO's Game of Thrones is a book about the tv show, Game of Thrones (duhh!). I have yet to read everything, but I've flipped through the pages multiple times. The book is absolutely beautiful and has some great images from the show in there. This book is normally quite expensive, but I managed to buy it for only £7.50!

The Golden Lily and The Indigo Spell by Richelle Mead

Book 2 and 3 of the Bloodlines Series by Richelle Mead! I picked up both books so that I could complete my set (until the next book comes out anyway). I've already read and reviewed The Golden Lily and I hope to read The Indigo Spell soon as well.

The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky

I read The Perks of Being a Wallflower in September 2012, but I didn't have my own copy which is why I picked it up in London. I love this book a lot and I hope to read it again soon.

World War Z by Max Brooks

The upcoming movie got me curious about the book and so I decided to buy it. I am currently reading the book and it's OK so far. I hope it'll get better. It's already clear though that the book and the movie don't have much in common.

The Knife of Never Letting Go by Patrick Ness

I have heard so many good things about The Knife of Never Letting Go that I just had to pick it up! It's quite a big book, but when I have some more spare time on my hands, I'll definitely read it!

Starcrossed by Josephine Angelini

Starcrossed was recommended to me and when I saw it for only £2, I decided to buy it.

Paper Towns and The Fault in Our Stars by John Green

I read The Fault In Our Stars in April last year. I loved it and wanted my own copy. I've been wanting to read some more John Green books, so that's why I bought Paper Towns as well.

Legend and Prodigy by Marie Lu

I've already read both Legend and Prodigy. After reading just Legend, I didn't feel the need to get my own copy, but I loved Prodigy so much that I decided to buy them anyway. That's a total of 11 books bought in London. I won't need to buy any more books for a while now (I think). Let me know if there's a book you'd like to see reviewed!

item.title: When In London: DVDs Bought
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Aside from buying a lot of books, there's another big temptation when you live in London and it's called HMV. The dvds there are just so cheap that it's very hard to walk out of the store without buying something. And well, sometimes I just couldn't resist! Here are the dvds I bought in London!

Game of Thrones Season 1 and 2

I absolutely love Game of Thrones and I couldn't just leave this dvd box there now could I?

Lost Season 5

Another one of my favorite TV Shows! I was still missing season 5 and 6 from my collection and so when I saw season 5 for a really cheap price, I picked it up. And I already re-watched the whole season! Now only season 6 is missing.

The Perks of Being a Wallflower

I bought the book and so all that was missing was the dvd. I think the movie is great too and I'm glad I own it now.

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone

Believe it or not, but I don't actually own every Harry Potter film on dvd (yet). I only started collecting them once I was allowed to buy them myself and for some reason it didn't cross my mind to buy the first ones as well. I've been searching for the dvds that have similar covers to the ones I already own, but I can't seem to find hem. So when I saw this first Harry Potter film, I decided to buy it anyway. Now I'm still missing the 2nd and 4th movie.

X-Men Trilogy and X-Men First Class

X-Men is one of my many favorite film series and so I couldn't help but pick up both the trilogy and X-Men First Class.

item.title: When In London: Markets Visited
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The markets in London are always a joy to visit and during my three months in London I made it a mission to visit a few of them. Here are to ones I got around to visiting.

Greenwich Market

Greenwich Market is beautiful! I went there two times, once on my own and again with my parents. It's not a very big market, but it's just very cozy and it's got some great stalls with everything from art to antiques to food. There's also a stall that's got stacks and stacks of books, which is my favorite! I can totally recommend going to Greenwich if you haven't done it yet, there's so much more to see. My parents had been to London a few times before already and they loved discovering Greenwich.

Old Spitalfields Market

Old Spitalfields Market is a small market in the Shoreditch area. I enjoyed it, even though it isn't that big. This is also the market where I discovered Shoe Embassy. They've got some great shoes!

Camden Market

Who doesn't know Camden Town? Even though this market is always crazy busy, it's definitely one of my favorites. I had already been to Camden when I was in London on Holiday and I went back three more times during those three months. It's quite a big market with all kinds of stalls for all kinds of people. The food there is quite amazing as well!

Brick Lane Market

I went to Brick Lane for the first time when my sister came to visit. We arrived there close to lunchtime and I was more than eager to try some of the food there. Bick Lane is filled with all kinds of stuff. There was a vintage section, food, clothes and accessories and much much more. One of the things I really liked was the graffiti.

Borough Market

It turns out that I don't actually have any pictures from my visit to Borough Market. I went there when four of my friends from school came to visit and I just didn't take any photos. However, Borough Market is a food market. We ate some yummy brownies there, but everything looked great. You could buy freshly baked (but expensive) bread there, among other things of course. Have you ever been to one of these markets? Did you like them? What other markets can you recommend?

item.title: When In London: Museums Visited
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
There's so much you can do in London and one of those things is visit their museums! I didn't get around to visiting all the museums that I wanted to, but I did visit these four.

Design Museum

The first museum on my list was the Design Museum. At the time of my visit, there were two exhibitions open: Designs of the Year 2013 and Extraordinary Stories About Ordinary Things. My favorite was the Designs of the Year. It included all kinds of design from graphic design to fashion to furniture. The number one design of the year was (spoiler alert) the Olympic Torch. The second exhibition included a look at some of the traffic and London Underground signs, more fashion and a lot of chairs. I mainly liked the way everything was presented there on the shelves. It's hard to explain, but those who've been there will (hopefully) know what I'm talking about.

London Transport Museum

My second museum visit was the London Transport Museum. Weird choice you may ask? Well, they were celebrating 150 years of London Underground and had a special exhibition with 150 of the best underground posters. I absolutely loved seeing all the different posters designs from throughout the years. Beautiful! I spent a bit of time looking at the different busses and all that stuff, but I can totally recommend the poster exhibition to those who love some awesome graphic design.

Natural History Museum

I went to the Natural History Museum with some friends who came to visit. We mainly wanted to go there because of the dinosaurs (since that was the theme of Designosource). We didn't see everything in the museum. The entry was free, so it didn't really matter how much you ended up seeing. The entrance of the museum is gorgeous (see image above) and it was pretty cool to see the dinosaur skeletons, but unfortunately it was quite busy and hot inside, so I was more eager to get outside and get some air than to walk around more.

Tate Modern

Another museum visit with the same friends. We didn't go to any of the paid exhibitions in Tate Modern, but we did go inside all the free ones. I didn't take any pictures inside, but I did take a few of the beautiful view! One of the free exhibitions had a photography section which I really loved. There were also some other art pieces I really liked. Maybe next time I'll go to a paid exhibition. Did you every visit any of these museums? Did you like them? Which museums do you plan to visit and which ones do you recommend?

item.title: When In London: Concerts Attended
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In April, I went to two concerts in London: Imagine Dragons and One Republic. Both concerts were in smaller venues, which I love, and both of them were a lot of fun! Here are some short reviews.

Imagine Dragons

On April 11th, 2013, Imagine Dragons performed in The Forum in Kentish Town, London. I was only recently introduced to the band and I loved them! So when a friend suggested I'd buy the ticket that was meant for her boyfriend (who didn't really want to go), I said yes! And I'm so glad that I did! The concert is one of my favorites until this date. On the day of the concert, their album had only been out in the UK for four days, but everyone there already knew every word to every song. The crowd went wild, especially with their hit song Radioactive. The band was amazing as well and if I get the chance, I'd definitely see them again!

One Republic

I used to be quite a big One Republic fan, especially around the time when their song "All The Right Moves" came out. My love for them had died down quite a lot after that. I had listened to their music so much, that I was sick of it. I had my doubts about going to the concert, but because I loved them once, I just decided to buy my ticket. About a month later, their new album Natives came out and I ended up loving it! It has some of their best songs, in my opinion. So yes, I ended up being quite excited to go to their concert! On April 24th, I went to the O2 in Shepherd's Bush with two friends to attend the concert. They didn't top Imagine Dragons for me, but it was a good concert nonetheless. The only thing that bothered me a bit was that they played quite a few covers, whereas I would've preferred to hear some more of their own music. It was a fun evening and I'm glad I saw them live, but I wouldn't go a second time. Oh, and for those who are confused. One Republic is NOT One Direction. Quite a few people I spoke to confused the two. Have you seen either Imagine Dragons or One Republic live? If yes, did you like the performance? If no, do you want to? What concert or festival plans do you have in the near future?

item.title: When In London: Favorite Places
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
London has so much more to offer than all the tourist locations. Sure, I love seeing all the classic London sights, but I ended up enjoying the places in London that surpassed me a lot more. Dani suggested that I'd do a Favorite Places in London blog as part of my "When In London"-series. It wasn't easy to select just a few, so I picked a few more touristic places and a few uniquer ones.

Greenwich

If it isn't obvious yet that I love Greenwich, I'll tell you again: I love Greenwich! This is an area that I think a lot of tourist don't know about or just don't get around to when they visit London. It has, however, become one of my favorite places in those three months. There's a great market, The Royal Observatory offers you an amazing view and the whole area is just beautiful!

Covent Garden

Covent Garden does attract quite a lot of tourist, especially where the market is, but I love it there nonetheless! Aside from that there's also some shopping to be done there and some really nice restaurants and pubs to visit. Either during the day or in the evening, it's a nice part of London!

Westfield

I like both the Westfield in Shepherd's Bush and in Stratford a lot. This is what I call a shopping mall and not the things we have in Belgium! I just really enjoy walking around there and aside from the awesome stores, there's also some great restaurants in there.

Canada Water

I doubt many people have heard of Canada Water in London. One of my colleagues lives in that area and so I ended up there a few times. I especially love the area right when you exit the station (see images above). Canada Water also has a pretty awesome library! I went in there once and the building itself is very interesting as well, not just the books they have!

Canary Warf Underground Station

I guess this is quite a strange answer as a favorite place. I had to enter the Canary Warf Underground Station everyday to go to work and I loved doing it. The station is big and absolutely beautiful! In the mornings, it's always filled with people (most of them going in the different direction than I was) and it's just so interesting to walk into the station everyday.

Go Up Office

Well, I did spend most of my time at the Go Up Office, so this answer shouldn't be that unusual. It's overall just a really nice office and Westbourne Studios is a fun building to work in. For those who hadn't noticed before, they have fake grass on the floor, which I think is a pretty nice touch! They also have a tiny ping pong table there, a football lying around and Winston either begging for food or sleeping.

Other places

Aside from the places I mentioned above, I also really like the area around the Millennium Bridge. Especially the view you have from Tate Modern, looking over the river, the bridge and St. Pauls Cathedral. I also spent quite a bit of time in different bookstores from Waterstones and Foyles to Skoob and London Review Bookshop. Overall, I truly love London and there's so much I have yet to discover there. Feel free to share your opinion on my favorite places. And what are you favorite places in London? Or the world?

item.title: Wrapping Up: Designosource
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For those who don't know, Designosource was my graduation project. We were a team of 12 student who functioned as a real company, under the guidance of 4 teachers. We worked on several projects and I thought it'd be nice to introduce them to you.

Overview

Working for Designosource for about 10 months was quite amazing! A big plus for me was that I didn't have to write a thesis, but would get to work with real clients on real projects. I ended up working on 5 out of the 8 projects we had. Looking back, I do think I probably should've picked more diverse projects, because most of the work I did was in Wordpress. So I didn't really end up improving my technical skills, but worked more on my soft skills. I gave the whole team a quick training on Wordpress theming, figured out how to work in teams of 4 to 6 people and so on. That we got to work with actual clients, was also a big step forward to our fellow students. We had meetings with the clients, had to communicate with them on a regular basis and had deal with a whole lot of emails, filled with a whole lot of wishes, changes and other requests. This helped a lot when starting my internship and it will be useful for future jobs as well. I still had to work for Designosource during those 3 months that I was in London. Every thursday, I would get up earlier and attend the morning meeting via Skype and I was available on Skype while I was at my internship. It wasn't easy combining work for school with my internship and being in London, but I managed. Aside from the actual work and the projects, we also had a great team and a lot of fun! I really enjoyed going to our office and working together with everyone and our teambuilding moments were always amazing!

Projects

Here are all the projects that the Designosource team ended up working on! You can find three of them in my portfolio. These are the ones were I contributed the most. Click on the images below to find out more about the projects: Nomad Chair, Soep 't erin and WJEC. Aside from those 3 projects, I also helped to build the Designosource website. I did some small tasks for the website, including a bit of Wordpress theming (which I later handed over to someone else) and some jQuery. One of the last projects I worked on was for Flow Pilots. Their projects existed of 2 parts: a landings page for their converstation app and making adjustments to their current website. I was responsible for adjusting one page of the website, but I had to pass that along to someone else in the team because I was in London and I wouldn't have been able to finish it in time. Unfortunately, they haven't updated their website with out changes yet. The other 3 projects that I wasn't a part of were 21bis (a news platform for the Journalism students of Thomas More), City Game (an iPad game to promote Office Management at Thomas More) and Justory (a platform that allows users to share stories about justice).

The End

We had to give a final presentation on June 18th for a jury, teachers, family, friends and potential employers. The presentation was very well received and we got some amazing feedback. We ended the year at Designosource very successfully, and the whole team passed. Now, Designosource is out of our hands and it'll be handed over to next year's third year students (or a selection of them anyway). I had a blast this past year and I am more than grateful to the whole Designosource team (including the teachers)!

item.title: Wrapping Up: Interactive Multimedia Design
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For the past 3 years, I've been studying Interactive Multimedia Design (IMD) at Thomas More Mechelen. Today I received my final results and I am more than happy to say that I GRADUATED! *does a happy dance*

Studying IMD

I guess I could briefly review my education. The education has changed quite a bit since I started it, because in the world of informatics you just have to keep up and keep changing. So yes, I can tell you what my experience was like, but those who started the same education this year and and those who will start it in September, will have quite a different course ahead of them. I think the first question to answer is whether or not I learned something in those three year. I did, but not really that much. Especially the first year wasn't that special to me. I already had a few years of experience working with HTML, CSS and Photoshop. The first year helped me improve my way of working, as well as finding my way around other Adobe programs like Illustrator and Flash. I did learn JavaScript and jQuery in my first year, which was great! In my second year, I had PHP classes and the projects were a bit more challenging. You can find some of the work I did in my second year in my portfolio (iPad Magazine, Fabric Factory Logo, School Assigments and Kabe & Ko). The final year was the most memorable one. The classes weren't that interesting anymore, except for the Mobile Platforms and Interactive Marketing classes. The reason I will remember it, is because I was part of Designosource and because of my amazing internship. I had way more different courses than I mentioned above, but I simply can't review all of them. I think IMD was a very good education were you get a good basic knowledge of both design and technical aspects that you can built on yourself.

Graduating

I won't have my official proclamation until October. This is for those who still need to retake some exams in August and September and then all of us can officially graduate together in October. I already passed for all of my courses, so I'll receive this temporary diploma until then. Nonetheless, I graduated and now it's time to start working! On Monday, I'm starting my last summer job at a local web company. I'll also start applying to different companies, so that I can start a full-time job in September. It's time to jump into the rather unknown world of a full-time job! Wish me luck!

item.title: The Bling Ring (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Yesterday I went to go see The Bling Ring, a movie starring Emma Watson, Katie Chang and Taissa Farmiga. The movie is inspired by true events and tells the story of a group of teenagers breaking into the homes of celebrities like Paris Hilton, Orlando Bloom and Rachel Bilson. I got introduced to this movie because of Emma Watson, but after seeing the trailer I got really interested in the movie itself. So I was more than happy that the movie is already out in Belgium and when my friends suggested that we should go see it. I think The Bling Ring is really good! It was surprisingly funny and the kind of movie that allowed you to just sit back and enjoy without too much brain activity. The story was very interesting, in my opinion. These characters are obsessed with the celebrity lifestyle and go as far as breaking into the homes of the celebrities they look up to and steal they clothes and jewelry. You can't really really relate or like the characters in this movie. They are very mean, selfish and not at all genuine, but I think that's part of the charm the movie. I liked the overall acting of the whole cast, but I have to point out Emma Watson for a second. Her American accent just isn't quite what it should be. I understand that it's hard to do when you're British and I probably paid a bit too much attention to it, but from time to time it would just be very obvious that she's pretending to be American. The movie was visually also very beautiful and well filmed. Overall it was just very entertaining to watch and I can really recommend the movie, though I'm not sure if it's for everyone. What did you think of The Bling Ring? Do you plan on seeing The Bling Ring? Let me know anything you want about The Bling Ring.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Bling Ring Movie Review | Joyce Van Herck | Web Designer
Joyce Van Herck's The Bling Ring Movie Review. It was surprisingly funny and the kind of movie that allowed you to just sit back and enjoy.

item.title: InstaDiary: June 2013
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: All packed and ready to go back to Belgium. / Rewatching Lost. / My dad and his coverband performing. / Finally posted a new Web Design Inspiration post on my blog. / Cinema tickets from London (read related blog). / Books bought in London. / Got sent this photo of my last evening out with the Go Up team. Good times! / DVDs bought in London. My Designosource character! / At Greenwich Market (read related blog). / Finished playing Tomb Raider 2013! What a great, but stressful game! / Started reading Paper Towns (and already finished it). / Last teambuilding moment with almost the whole Designosource team! / Movie time! / Found my name on a Coke bottle! / Went to see The Bling Ring with some friends. I'm done with school forever, so I decided to clean out my closet and get rid of whatever was left over from all those years of school. Ended up with a laundry basket full of papers to throw out. / Also reorganised the posters on my wall. / Finally started to read Inside HBO's Game of Thrones. What a beautiful book! / Watched The Hunger Games again. That's it for the month of June!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: InstaDiary: June 2013 | Joyce Van Herck | Front-End Designer
Joyce Van Herck's InstaDiary of June 2013. First month back in Belgium after spending 3 months in London.

item.title: World War Z (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In World War Z, Gerry Lane (played by Brad Pitt) tries to stop a Zombie pandemic that's threatening all of humanity. I am currently reading the book, but once I realised that the book and movie are nothing alike, I thought I might as well go see the movie already. World War Z is not the best movie ever or anything, but it managed to entertain me and keep me on the edge of my seat nonetheless. So, where to start with World War Z? The movie starts off quite well by using a Muse song for the intro. They used the song a few other times during the movie as well. Anyway, another good start of the movie is that it jumps right in. Right from the moment that the characters realise that something is wrong, I was on the edge of my seat, curious to see what would happen! And even though they don't actually show any violence in the movie (meaning, the violence is all implied and you don't actually see any gore), it managed to surprise and shock me quite a number of times. One thing that did bother me a bit was the amount of human stupidity! I guess they needed to let the characters bump into stuff or make noise, because what fun would it be to just let them sneak past the zombies? But that didn't take away that it was very obvious that it was just for that reason and it sort of made the characters look somewhat stupid. I'd say the zombies in World War Z were fine. It was interesting to have zombies that can actually run quite fast. The computer animated zombies in the first half of the movie didn't bother me. I actually quite enjoyed those overview shots from the sky where you could see people/zombies running around in the streets. The "real" zombies were the most interesting though! I don't know what else to say. No, World War Z wasn't amazing or anything, but it managed to hold my attention from beginning to end, it scared the hell out of me and I simply had a good time. If you like a good action movie, combined with some apocalyptic and horror elements, you should see this movie (though maybe not in the cinema). What's your opinion on World War Z? Do you want to see World War Z? Let me know anything you want about World War Z in the comments!

IMDb | Trailer

World War Z is not the best movie ever, but it managed to keep me on the edge of my seat nonetheless. This is my World War Z Movie Review.

item.title: Orange is the New Black (TV Show Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Orange is the New Black is a Netflix TV Show that aired earlier this month. The show follows Piper Chapman when she ends up in a women's prison for something she did in her past. When I saw the trailer for this show, I decided to give it a chance and I was pleasantly surprised! I wasn't sure what to expect from this show. Based on the trailer it looked like it could be rather funny and in a way it certainly was was. But this show has so much more to offer! It was interesting to see how Piper Chapman, a college educated and rather spoiled person, tries to handle herself in all those different situations. It's fun to see how see attempts to learn the rules of prison and attempts to remain strong. Aside from Chapman's story, you also get to meet a lot of the other inmates and discover their story about how they ended up in prison. I think all of the characters were great, as well as the acting and just the overall storyline. For those interested: the show is based on true events and there's also a book that was used as source material. I only have good things to say about this show and I really recommend it! I'm truly sad that I don't have any episodes left to watch, but luckily they already ordered a second season! Are you interested in watching Orange is the New Black? Or if you've you already seen it: what are your thoughts on the show?

item.title: The Knife of Never Letting Go (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Knife of Never Letting Go is the first book in the Choas Walking Trilogy written by Patrick Ness. It tells the story of Todd Hewitt. He is the only boy left in a town called Prentisstown. A town full of men. A town where everyone can hear each others thoughts. A month before the day he becomes a man, he discovers that the town is hiding something and he is forced to run. The first thing that I have to say is that this book took me by surprise! I had heard so many good things about the whole series and that's also why I ended up buying the book. I didn't even really know what to story was about, but I am more than happy that I picked it up! I wasn't sure that I wanted to start reading this book when I did. Even though I had heard good things about it, the book is almost 500 pages and I was afraid it would take me a while to get through. I was wrong though! Reading this book was an absolute joy and it was hard to put down! The "New World" as it is called in the book is so interesting! Another great aspect of the story is that you discovered the world right along with Todd. Everything he knew about the world he lives in was a lie and together with him, you discover the truth. The "hearing each others thoughts" part of the story is quite different than I expected it to be. The thoughts are called Noise in the book and aren't just loud and clear thoughts, but they are just that: Noise. Just bits and pieces of what people are thinking. In my copy of the book the Noise also had different typography, which I loved! One thing that was a bit difficult about the writing for me was the "grammatical errors". It's supposed to be that way, so no it's not and error from the publishing company or anything, but you read the story the way Todd pronounces words or in the dialects of the other characters. At times it was a bit difficult when passing a word that's "miss-spelled" or written a certain way. Sometimes I needed to read it a few times to figure out the actual word. On the other hand this is part of the charm is the story and I did get used to it in the end. I honestly almost wished that I hadn't finished the book just yet or that I had already bought the sequel so that I could read it, because that last chapter just leaves me wanting more! More of the world, more of the characters! Just more! So yeah, I guess it's quite obvious that I love this book and that I really recommend it! I gave it 5/5 stars on Goodreads.

Goodreads | Buy The Knife of Never Letting Go

item.title: Harken (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Harken tells the story of a character named Michael Asher, who is known for being able to discover what people are feeling by looking into their eyes. After an assassination attempt he discovers a conspiracy theory and has to figure out why this group of supernatural beings wants him dead. I love Kaleb Nation and I was very excited to read Harken, but it let me down. Let me start off by saying once again that I really do love Kaleb Nation. I think he is an amazing YouTuber and I've been watching his videos for years. Kaleb did an amazing job at hyping up and marketing this book. He got me really excited to read Harken and well, the plot just sounded really interesting. I don't think this book was bad, but I don't think it was great either. It definitely has its ups and downs. There were parts I really enjoyed reading and parts that just didn't do it for me. The characters in the book are good, but I wasn't that invested in them as I would've liked. I think the main character, Michael, just needed to stop whining and get his shit together. The more I learned about it, to more it confused me why he was so insecure and not that good of a leader. The characters that I really did like were Alli, Spud and Thad. I think they should play a bigger role in the sequel. There's also a little romance going on in the book, but all of it seemed a bit too random to me. I feel like there was never any build up towards these moments in the book. I do think the overall story and concept of this book was great, but it was quite predictable at times. Luckily, there were a few plot twists that did take me by surprise. Another thing that made it a bit harder to really get into this book and liking it was the writing. I'm sorry Kaleb, but it just didn't grab my attention. I found my thoughts wandering off quite a few times. There were also quite a few spelling mistakes left in a book, which is unfortunate. I do understand that every author has to start somewhere and I can only hope that Kaleb's writing will improve over time. I really have to hand it to Kaleb for creating so much hype around this book. I am quite disappointed that I didn't end up loving it, because I really did want to. However, this is just a summary of things that I didn't like and for those who are interested in reading this book, I would tell you to give it a try anyway. You might find yourself really liking the book, like so many others out there.

Goodreads | Buy Harken

What are your thoughts about Harken? Have you read the book or do you plan to read it?

item.title: The Indigo Spell (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Indigo Spell is the third book in the Bloodlines series by Richelle Mead. The Indigo Spell is better than the second book, The Golden Lily, and makes me long for the fourth book to come out. In The Indigo Spell, Sydney Sage has a whole lot to deal with. She has to solve the mystery of Marcus Finch, takes her magic to a new level as a new threat appears and struggles with the feelings she has for someone she is supposed to disgust. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book from the first page until the last. Compared to the second book, The Indigo Spell has so much more to offer! I absolutely loved reading every moment between Sydney and Adrian and I love the character that is Sydney more than ever. Also, the short appearances of Rose, Dimitri and Lissa were a nice addition to the story. The only thing I missed a bit in this book is the interaction between Sydney and Jill, Eddie and Angeline. It seems like she rarely saw or spoke with them at all. The few moments she did have with them were fun to read though. The ending of this book makes me really curious and excited for what Richelle Mead has in store for these characters in The Fiery Heart! This is a rather short review of The Indigo Spell, but overall I really loved this book and I have nothing more to say than to go ahead an read it! Have you read The Indigo Spell? Do you agree with me or do you have a different opion? If you haven’t read it, do you plan to?

Buy The Indigo Spell | Goodreads
