item.title: The 5th Wave (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The 5th Wave by Rick Yancey tells the story of Cassie, a lone survivor after an alien invasion. Don't let the "alien invasion" aspect turn you off, because The 5th Wave is one of the best books I've read in a while! I honestly don't have that much to say about The 5th Wave, because this book was simply amazing. I don't actually read that many alien invasion stories, but this book is a must-read! The aliens in this story take of the world and attempt to kill off humans in several waves. Throughout the story you discover how Cassie experienced these waves and how she ended up alone. All of it is just incredibly interesting! The story is told through different narraters, Cassie being the main one. This is a thing that threw me off a bit in the beginning, because I don't normally enjoy switching perspectives. In this story, however, it worked so well! The 5th Wave could very well be a standalone book, but because of how awesome it is, I am actually glad that this book is part of a trilogy. I've grown to love these characters so much and I would love nothing more than to find out more about the rest of their survival and war with the aliens. You definitely don't need to like alien invasion stories to enjoy this book. I think anyone who enjoys Fantasy/Science Fiction YA will love this book! So just go ahead and pick up this book! If you've read The 5th Wave, let me know in the comments what your thoughts are on the book. If you haven't read it, let me know if you plan on doing so.

item.title: Under the Dome (Season 1 Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In Under the Dome, the town of Chester's Mill gets cut off from the rest of the world by a dome. The dome basically locks a bunch of crazy people and psychopaths in together. I was really interested in this show when I first heard about it, but unfortunately it was unable to live up to my expectiations. Under the Dome is based on a book by Stephen King. I had not (yet) read the book, so I can't compare it to the source material. I found out about this show quite early on and I was genuinely interested in the concept of it. However, when the cast was announced I wasn't so sure anymore. Britt Robertson is part of the cast and after seeing her in "The Secret Circle".. Let's just say I'm not a fan of hers. I was excited about Rachelle Lefevre being in the show, because I think she's an amazing person! I think the first few episodes of this show were ok. I wasn't amazed or anything but I was interested in what was going to happen and just curious how the whole concept would unfold. This, however, didn't last too long as I soon began to realise that this show wasn't going to get much better. The writing and the dialogue of this show is pretty terrible. Everything is just so cliché. You could make the show more entertaining by predicting what the characters are going to say next. Really, it's not that hard. And because of the terrible writing, the acting in Under the Dome leaves much to be desired. Britt Robertson confirmed why I didn't like her to begin with. All the teenagers in this show are just bleh and even a more experienced actor like Dean Norris failed to interest me. There was one episode in the whole season that showed promise: the second to last episode. Episode 12 was the best episode of the season and implied a great season finale. Which, unfortunately we didn't get. The season finale fell flat. Big time! I still think that the concept of this show has a lot of potential but it simply fails to deliver. Have you seen Under the Dome yet? What did you think? Was/is Under the Dome on your to-watch list?

item.title: I found a job!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you would've asked me 6 to 7 months ago what I would be doing right now, I would've told you that I would still be studying. But then I went to London to do an internship and that completely changed my mind. So after I graduated in June, I decided that I wanted to start working after all. First, I went looking for a last summer job and then it was time for the real work: job hunting! After I finished school I decided to grab the opportunity to do a last summer job. I got a job at a local web agency in a matter of a few days. Doing this summer job didn't just allow me to earn a fair amount of money, but it also gave to me some extra time before I had to start job hunting for a full time position. I have to admit that job hunting did scare me a bit. For a little while it seemed like I might be offered a full time job at my internship company, but due to financial reasons that fell through. And so my search for a job began. I decided that I didn't want to give up London and that I would apply at companies in Flanders and London. The first few weeks I spent most of my time looking for interesting companies and vacancies. About half way through my summer job, I sent out my first job applications. The Monday after that I already got a reply back (from the company I work at now) that they would invite me for an interview in August. The next month or so, I kept sending out applications (both to vacancies and spontaneous applications) to all kinds of companies, but the amount of replies was rather disappointing. There were quite a few moments where I started to doubt my skills. I'd say that job hunting overall can be quite discouraging because there are very few companies that actually take a minute to reply. Mid-August, I finally got some positive feedback and I ended up being invited by 3 companies for an interview. All of those interviews went surprisingly well. I expected to be more nervous than I was, but it turns out it's not that hard to talk about something you're passionate about. I was invited for a second round at all 3 companies. At 2 companies I also had to do a little assignment to test my skills. And then the biggest surprise of all (for me anyway): I got offered a job at all 3 companies. I had quite a though decision to make. All ends well though, I'm currently working at BLEND and I already had a great first week there. It took me a little over 2 months to find a job.

Some job hunting tips

I'm not a pro at job hunting by a long shot, but there are a few tips that I would like to share with those who are currently looking for a job. These tips probably aren't applicable in every sector, but for the industry I'm in (web design & development) they seem to work. A tip that everyone probably already knows about is to design your cv. Keep in mind that it's incredibly boring for companies to go through stacks of cvs and cover letters. You could make it more interesting for them by standing out with a well-designed cv. Another tip is to write a different cover letter for every company you apply to. Read the vacancy and include things in your letter that are mentioned there. This proves that you read the vacancy properly. It also doesn't hurt to have a good look at the company website to see if there's something you could mention in your letter. It's a lot of work to write a proper cover letter for every company, I know, but it's so important! Do try to keep it brief though and make sure you have something left to talk about at the job interview. Something else I discovered during my job hunt is that social media can really help! I mentioned in my Twitter profile description that I was looking for a job and I also changed my Twitter header to emphasize this. On LinkedIn you can change your headline (the line under your name) to say that you are looking for new opportunities. I got contacted by several consultancy agencies through LinkedIn and although they didn't have any positions that were interesting for me, it might help in some other industries. I also got contacted through Twitter a few times, asking me to send my cv and some other information. Job hunting definitely isn't the most fun to do in life. If anything, it's the most annoying thing. I'm lucky to have found a job in only 2 months, but they were quite stressful months for me. I wish everyone who is reading this the best of luck with whatever they are/want to be doing.

item.title: Where Do You Get Your Blogging Inspiration?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Those of you who keep an eye on my blog have probably noticed that I haven't posted anything since my InstaDiary at the beginning of the month. Every weekend of this past month, I have made myself sit down to try and write some blog posts, but it just didn't happen. I didn't know what to write about and the inspiration seemed to stay far away. My website is getting close to its 6th birthday already, but this past year has definitely been the most successful when it comes to blogging. I started blogging again a year ago (October 30th, 2012) and now it seems that I'm in a bit of a slump. I normally get my blogging inspiration out of everyday life. Wether it's just a book I read, a movie I watched and want to review or a life experience that I want to share. Reading other blogs also help, although the blogs I follow don't always cover similar subjects. I follow several fashion and beauty blogs, but it's not something that I would blog about myself. Anyway, I haven't been getting inspired by my everyday life, so I suppose it's time for me to get out there I do something more with my evenings and weekends. And maybe it's also time to look for some new blogs to follow. I started my first professional job at the end of September, but my evenings and weekends have been rather lazy since then. I did get to do quite a lot of experimenting with websites at work, so I might start posting tutorials and post about useful plugins for building websites. I also want to redesign my website, but that might take some time since I have no idea which direction I want to go in. I really hope to pick up blogging again, but what I really want to know is what you do to get inspired? What blogs inspire you? Which environments inspire you? What do you do when you're out of ideas?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Where Do You Get Your Blogging Inspiration? | Joyce Van Herck

Anyway, I always love seeing your blog post on what you are working on for work etc. depending of course if you are allowed to post that, but those are great fun to see ^^

I suck with blog inspiration as well, I never really know what to write.. It's easier now here in London though as I do more stuff than back at home.. I guess if all your days are the same there's not much you can write about, unless something really nice happens even if it's just something small.

I find it quite hard as well, all though I have been doing quite alright on posting a lot. Try to keep to yourself and mix things up once in a while. And if you get a job of course it's hard, you're away all day and just want to chill out when you get home. I try to do some recipes once in a while and take my photo whenever I can. Try to find some columns and react, make weekly posts with one subject, tags... I just try to get inspiration from everywhere really, our apartment, talking to people, internet, the city and a lot more. But yes, it's definitely not easy. Hope that helps!

London is a lot more inspiring than the small town I live in now, but I just need to get out some more to get inspired. And maybe it's time for me to start taking some more photos too! Thanks, Nieke!
London is a great source of inspiration, isn't it? :) Thanks for your comment!
Thanks Arlette! I do plan on posting about my work, but it's not like there's a new project that goes live every week. But I'll definitely blog about the projects I'm allowed to blog about :).

item.title: Just Dance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Here's something I realised I've never talked about in my blogs: dancing. I've been dancing for about 10 to 11 years now and even though I don't consider myself a very good dancer, it's something I'm very passionate about. I've lost track of the amount of years I've been taking classes in the different dance styles, but I've mostly been following both Hip Hop and Jazz classes. Sometimes my dance school organises master classes where amazing choreographers and dancers (mostly known from So You Think You Can Dance) come to our school to teach us new techniques and awesome choreographies. Below are some photos from the last few years. Some of the choreographers that you can see in the pictures below: Meysam Noori, Stefano Giuliani, Lauren Flament, Min Hee Bervoets and Floris Bosveld. Do you dance or like to dance?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wat een toffe foto's! Vind het altijd leuk om te lezen waar mensen een passie voor hebben. Ik heb zelf 1 jaar Jazzballet gedaan en gedanst in de musical (Moulin Rouge) op mijn middelbare school. Vond het erg leuk maar was te druk met andere sport en heb het daarom laten vallen. Vind het wel altijd erg tof om naar te kijken! :)

Awesome! Ik heb zelf ook iets van 10 jaar ballet gedaan, maar ik was ook geen superdanser, alhoewel ik het altijd heel erg graag gedaan heb. Ik ben ermee gestopt omdat ik er geen tijd meer voor had, maar ik mis het wel. Ik herbeleef mijn passie een beetje door iedere zondag aan mijn tv gekluisterd naar So You Think You Can Dance te zitten kijken, haha! Ik zou heel graag nog eens jazz willen leren, dat lijkt me echt heel tof om te doen. En super tof dat je die lessen hebt kunnen meedoen met al die topchoreografen en dansers zeg!
Ah awesome pictures! I never did much dancing as a kid, I'm horrible with it haha. But I can see you're passionate about it! :)

item.title: A Bunch of Awesome Movie Trailers #2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Since I'm excited about a few films coming out, I thought I'd do another trailer post.

The Book Thief

I've already heard so much about this book, but it only really grabbed my attention when I saw this trailer. I think this looks great! This film comes out on November 8th in the US, January 31st in the UK, February 19th in Belgium and March 13th in the Netherlands.

Divergent

Ok, so if I'm completely honest then I don't think this trailer is that awesome at all, but that doesn't take away the fact that I'm quite excited about this movie coming out. I love the books and I'm hoping the movie will be at least a little bit good. Divergent doesn't have a Belgian release date yet, but is expected to come out in the Netherlands on March 20th, in the US on March 21st and in the UK on April 4th.

The Hunger Games: Catching Fire

When I first started writing this posts "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" wasn't out yet. Since then I've seen the film and I loved it! I added the trailer to this list anyway because I want to go see it again! Catching Fire is out everywhere so go see it!

X-Men: Days of Future Past

How awesome does this look? I love X-Men (especially X-Men: First Class) and the cast is amazing! This is a recipe for an awesome film, don't you think? I can't wait for this to come out! The Belgian Release date is set op May 21t. The Netherlands in UK have wait an extra day (May 22nd) and the USA another day (May 23rd). What movies are you excited for?

item.title: A Batch of Movie Reviews: Animated Movies
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Over the past two months, I spent some time catching up on the latest animated movies and I thought I would take the time to briefly review them! Here are some short reviews of the latest Ice Age and Madagascar movies, as well as Wreck-It Raplh, Despicable Me 2 and Monsters University.

Ice Age: Continental Drift

Overall I've really enjoyed watching the Ice Age movies and this one was no different. I liked the story of this one and the villain was great! Sure it was quite cliché, but there were some funny moments. If you've seen the previous Ice Age movies, you should definitely check this one out.

Madagascar: Europe's Most Wanted

I liked the first Madagascar movie, but for me it kind of went down hill from there. I personally think this was the worst one yet. It did have some good moments: I really liked the circus part of the story, but overall it just wasn't that entertaining and some of the effects for their circus performances were a little over the top in my opinion.

Wreck-It Ralph

Wreck-It Ralph really took me by surprise. I wasn't all that interested when I first saw the trailer. I hardly know any of the games that are included in the movie, but it was still very fun for me to watch. I love seeing Ralph explore these other games and I think the characters were pretty fun. I do think they made Vanellope look a bit too much like Agnes from Despicable Me, but once I got to know her character all was forgiven. I really recommend Wreck-It Ralph, even if you've never even heard of the games that are mentioned.

Despicable Me 2

I'm a big Despicable Me fan! I was a little bit worried that the second movie wouldn't be as good, but I'm glad to say that I really enjoyed it! They went in a different direction with the plot, there's some romance and who doesn't love those minions? I totally recommend this if you liked the first movie.

Monsters University

Monsters University was freaking adorable! It had a predictable plot (pretty much all animated movies do), but I enjoyed watching this so much! I loved the story of how Mike and Sullivan became friends and all of the new characters were fun as well. I think this is a must-watch if you like watching animated movies. If you've seen any of these movie, let me know what you thought of them in the comments!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ik heb Despicable Me 2 in de bioscoop gezien en vond de film hilarisch. Heb heel erg veel gelachen, de minions zijn zo leuk. Wreck it Ralph wil ik nog steeds heel graag zien. ;)
Nice reviews! Monsters University is my favorite from this list! ♥
Ik moet eerlijk bekennen dat ik van veel films die je hier vermeld hebt de originelen nog niet gezien heb... Maar dat wil ik zeker nog doen, voor Monster Inc. ben ik heel benieuwd naar!

item.title: My Reading Story
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Everybody has a story about how they started reading. Some loved reading every since they were able to read. Others have books like Harry Potter that made them fall in love with reading. The latter is part of my reading story. As I kid, I was never too crazy about the reading. I have always been a big fan of the Kiekeboe comics and for a long time that was all I really enjoyed to read. I do remember going to the library quite often. I never liked the mandatory reading, but every once in a while I would pick up some books by Marc de Bel or other Flemish child authors. Somewhere around the age of 9, I received the first four Harry Potter books as a gift from my aunt. At the time everybody was reading Harry Potter. I read the books too, but I can't say I appreciated them. I didn't like to read and I wasn't exactly excited to read such big books. Then near the end of elementary school, I was gifted a book from my parents: "Hoe overleef ik mezelf?" (How do I survive myself?) by Francine Oomen, an author from the Netherlands. This book slightly altered my opinion about reading. I wasn't loving it yet, but I did love Francine Oomen's "How do I survive..?"-series! And then about 1 to 2 years later it happened: I finally decided to continue reading the Harry Potter books and I picked up Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix. And that's when I fell in love with reading. I immediately asked my mother to buy the next book in the series and I haven't stopped reading since. When the last book in the Harry Potter series came out I decided that I couldn't wait 3 more months for the Dutch translation to come out and so I received Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows in English as an early birthday present! The Deathly Hallows was the first book I ever read in English and I remember being surprised by how easy it was! I did end up getting and reading the Dutch translation as well, just to be 100% sure that I didn't miss anything. Another 2 years later, Twilight caught my attention and I think that every since then, there hasn't been a time where I wasn't reading a book. You can check out my Goodreads account to see what other books I've read or want to read. Be sure to add me as a friend if you have an account as well! What about you? Did you love reading ever since you were little? Do you like to read? Tell me your reading story in the comments!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ik hou van Harry Potter! Ik was vroeger als kind niet echt een lezer ook, pas op de middelbare school toen we verplicht boeken moesten lezen voor Nederlands, begon ik lezen leuk te vinden c; Ik vind 'Hoe Overleef Ik Series' van Francine Oomen super! Ook Carry Slee boeken :P Xx

Ah nice post! :) Hoe Overleef Ik, ahhh childhood! I used to read those as well haha.. Francine Oomen and Carry Slee used to be my favorite writers as a kid! Even though I did not read all of them.. I just thought of this book I really liked as a kid, I should read it again soon!

Wat leuk om te lezen! :) Ik ben altijd eigenlijk gek geweest op lezen. Ik las ook altijd strips op jongere leeftijd maar was meer van Donald Duck en Asterix & Obelix. Hoe overleef heb ik ook allemaal gelezen en was een grote fan van Carry Slee en Blauwe Plekken van Anke de Vries. Ik was 8 toen ik mijn eerste Harry Potter boek las en heb toen meteen tot deel 3 uitgelezen. Daarna ook Twilight en vele anderen boeken, ben nooit zo'n fan geweest van Nederlandse literatuur al moest ik dat wel lezen voor school. Maar lezen is nog steeds een grote hobby. :)

Erg leuke blogpost! Ik was ook heel erg fan van de Kiekeboe strips toen ik jonger was. Ik heb er nog heel veel liggen thuis (ik denk een stuk of 100) en ik vind het nog steeds leuk om ze eens af en toe te lezen. Ik las als kind al vrij veel, meer dan de meeste andere kinderen in mijn klas. Ik was vaak een van de weinige kinderen die het leuk vonden als er leesoefeningen waren of als er een boekbespreking aankwam. Ik was vooral fan van de Dolfje Weerwolfje serie van Paul van Loon, en ik toen ik wat ouder was heb ik veel boeken van Dirk Bracke gelezen. Maar ik ben pas echt gaan beseffen wat voor een grote boekenworm ik ben door Harry Potter. Door Twilight ben ik veel meer andere boeken en auteurs gaan ontdekken, zoals The Hunger Games, en zo heb ik ook de grote leescommunity ontdekt die op Youtube en internet te vinden is. Ik zou mezelf niet echt kunnen voorstellen zonder het feit dat ik een grote lezer ben.

Ik koop nu soms nog Kiekeboe strips als ik zie dat de prijs laag staat.. Het blijft leuk om te lezen! Dirk Bracke heb ik ook gelezen vroeger en door Twilight is er voor mij ook een wereld van boeken opengegaan!
Nederlandse of Vlaamse literatuur is ook nooit helemaal mijn ding geweest. Van zodra ik doorhad dat ik in het Engels kon lezen ben ik er niet meer mee gestopt!
Leuk om te lezen dat er nog mensen zijn die de HOI-serie gelezen hebben :-). Carry Slee heb ik niet echt gelezen. Ik hield het volgens mij (onbewust) meer bij Vlaamse auteurs toen ik jong was.
Harry Potter is het beste ooit! Ik vond het verplicht lezen op school nooit leuk. Het was pas toen ik zelf boeken mocht ontdekken en kiezen dat ik er begon van te houden!

item.title: The BLEND Website is Live!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Designing and building a website for your own web agency is usually the hardest project you can get. During my internship and some summer jobs, I had been a part of helping with their own websites. Your own website is something that gets pushed aside, because clients come first. It's something that takes forever because you want it to be the most perfect thing on the world wide web. The website for BLEND was no different. For the past (almost) 2 months, I've been working at an agency called BLEND. Right when I arrived my first priority was the company website. BLEND had a temporary website for way too long and it was finally time to get it going. The big lines of the design were already there when I arrived, but that didn't really mean anything. As usual, a lot of changes were made along the way. It was a month long building and changing process that included a lot of technical challenges. I'm more of a front-end developer (= the things you see when you visit a website), but I had to do some back-end development (= the code that happens in the background) for this as well. For those of you with some technical skills, here are some tools I used for the BLEND website: HTML5 Video, Chart.js and Isotope. So, the website. There's a lot of fun stuff in there. One thing you should definitely have a good look at is the island on the homepage. I won't tell you what to do, but I hope you figure it out! About is also an interesting page and well, my face is on there.

So go ahead and visit BLEND.BE and let me know what you think in the comments!

Ik ga als ik op een andere internet verbinding zit nog eens goed kijken, want hij laad wat traag hier. Maar ziet er awesome uit :D Leuk gedaan zo met het exotic island :)

item.title: Interview with Lauren Kate
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: On november 9th, I went to the book fair in Antwerp (Boekenbeurs) to interview Lauren Kate. Lauren is the author of the popular Fallen series and she's currently on a book tour to promote her new book, Teardrop. She made a stop in Antwerp on the YA Book Convention day at the book fair. She had a panel where fans could ask questions and a signing sessions. After that it was time for Yasmine, Robin and I to interview her for Fandicted.nl. We asked her questions related to her writing, the Fallen series, the Fallen movie and her new book. I filmed the interview, but unfortunately the audio isn't too great. We were in a small room in the middle of the book fair and you can still hear a lot of the background noise. Anyway, if you're interested you can watch the interview below! I want to thank Lauren Kate for her time and WPG Uitgevers for the opportunity!

item.title: "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" World Premiere in London
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: On November 11th, the world premiere of "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" took place in London's Leicester Square. I'm a huge Hunger Games fan and I figured that since a lot of the cast was coming out to London, I should do the same. I arrived in London on Sunday, the day before the premiere. Nieke and her boyfriend were kind enough to let me stay at their place. When I arrived, we decided to have a look on Twitter to find out if anyone was camping out already for the premiere. From what we could see on Twitter there were already some people camping out, but to make sure we decided to head over the Leicester Square to see what was going on. Once we found the group of campers, we found out that there were already about a hundred people there! We, however, didn't feel like spending the night on the streets of London, so we decided to take the risk to come back the next morning. I spent the rest of my day with my ex-colleagues from my internship. That evening Nieke and I talked back and forward with Danielle for a bit and we decided to start camping out at 4am! [caption id="attachment_3252" align="alignnone" width="670"] Leicester Square at 4am[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3251" align="alignnone" width="670"] My number[/caption] So after only a few hours of sleep, it was time to get up and go to Leicester Square! We met up with Dani and her friends and signed up for our numbers. To our own surprise we were numbers 231 to 236! Dani's friends came to London by car and they were kind enough to bring 5 camping chairs with them. So thanks to them we didn't have to sit on the cold, wet ground. The first few hours after that went by rather fast. At 6am we were placed in a queue in the order of our numbers and moved out of the square so that they could setup for the premiere. [caption id="attachment_3250" align="alignnone" width="670"] Our "Tea Party"[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3253" align="alignnone" width="670"] Waiting[/caption] We ended up on the street corner of Withcomb St and Orange St and had our so-called Tea Party there! I have to say.. to the people walking by it really must've looked like a gathering of homeless people. Everyone was wearing hats, scarfs and gloves. There were people with sleeping bags and cardboard boxes to keep themselves warm. Luckily, we were given permission to leave our spot for a few hours until we had to be moved back into the square. We took the time to go to Costa to keep warm. We had to be back at our corner spot by 10am, but we didn't get moved until a few hours later. Around noon it was finally time for everyone to be moved back into Leicester Square to find a spot for the actual premiere. With our numbers we were still able to find a great spot at the front row! [caption id="attachment_3254" align="alignnone" width="670"] The Mockingjay[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3255" align="alignnone" width="670"] Waiting some more[/caption] After being moved into the square, the exhaustion started to set in. The next hours until the premiere seemed endless. But somehow we managed and at around 5pm things slowly started. At first there was a presenter who had to warm up the crowd and then the livestream presenter took over and spoiled the movie by showing some clips (and I tried to hard no to watch them!). I was getting rather impatient though, because they seemed to be dragging out the actual arrival of the cast. [caption id="attachment_3256" align="alignnone" width="670"] Willow Shields (photo by Dani)[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3257" align="alignnone" width="670"] Stanley Tucci (photo by Dani)[/caption] The first to arrive was Willow Shields, who plays Prim (Katniss' little sister). She was sent to the press area almost straight away and it took almost 20 minutes for anyone else to arrive after her. I forgot in which order everyone arrived, but I remember Stanley Tucci (Caesar Flickerman) getting close to us.. Though not close enough to give us an autograph. I remember Josh Hutcherson (Peeta) arriving, waving and smiling to us before he started his interview round. [caption id="attachment_3258" align="alignnone" width="670"] Liam Hemsworth[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3259" align="alignnone" width="670"] Jena Malone[/caption] The first one to go all the way around the square for autographs and pictures was Liam Hemsworth (Gale). After him, it took forever for anyone else to come by. For a moment there, we thought we had picked the absolute worst spot in the square ever and that we wouldn't see anyone else. In the last half hour or so, our luck did seem to change! Jena Malone (Johanna Mason) came our way and she was so kind to everyone! She asked us how we were doing and she really took her time to give everyone and autograph and even a picture. Even when her agent told her it was time to leave, she quickly went over to some other people to give them an autograph as well. [caption id="attachment_3260" align="alignnone" width="670"] Jennifer Lawrence..[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3261" align="alignnone" width="670"] .. more Jennifer[/caption] Then we saw the amazing Jennifer Lawrence! Everyone in our area started screaming and chanting her name! However, when this adorable moment took place with a fan in a wheelchair everyone shut up to give the two some time together. Once Jennifer moved away from the little fan, we started yelling for her again and she came over! Things suddenly went crazy as everyone got really excited! [caption id="attachment_3262" align="alignnone" width="670"] Josh...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3263" align="alignnone" width="670"] ...Hutcherson[/caption] After that it was Josh Hutcherson who came over! People started pushing like their lives depended on it. Josh was really kind though and he was looking absolutely gorgeous! [caption id="attachment_3264" align="alignnone" width="670"] Sam Claflin and his beautiful smile[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3265" align="alignnone" width="670"] Sam Claflin[/caption] Sam Caflin (Finnick Odair) came after that and he was so excited! He did a little jump before he came our way and signed as many autographs as he could. The pushing was getting rather unbearable by that point and luckily Sam, his agent and security guy started asking people to stop pushing, finally giving me a moment to grasp some air! I have to say that Sam knows how to get the fans excited. His livestream interviews was great and weird at the same time. Sugarcubes! [caption id="attachment_3266" align="alignnone" width="540"] Selfie while waiting[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3267" align="alignnone" width="540"] After the premiere![/caption] Elizabeth Banks (Effie), Donald Sutherland (President Snow), Jeffrey Wright (Beete) and director Francis Lawrence were also at the premiere, but we only watched them walk by. Donald said in this livestream interview that he was cold, so I assume that he went inside rather quickly. But you don't hear my complain! Seeing Jennifer, Josh, Liam, Jena and Sam up close was all I needed to make the camping out in the rain and cold worth it. I had a great time and I am so grateful to the cast that came out! I will be seeing "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" on November 21st at a marathon, which I'm very excited for. Thanks for reading this incredibly long and fangirly post!

item.title: 20 Books and 10 Graphic Novels of 2013
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 2013 was a very different year for me and this is something that reflected on my reading this year. I had a 3-month internship in London, graduated, had a 4-week summer job, a 2-month job hunt and started my first full-time job at the end of September. I probably should've guessed at the beginning of this year that I wouldn't have that much time to read. At the beginning of 2013, I set my reading goal to 35 books. I read 33 books last year and I didn't see any problem in reading two more. However, not being in school anymore is a whole different thing and I didn't have as much time to read. There were a few months as well were I just didn't feel the need to read. So I ended up reducing my reading goal to 30 and I read some graphics novels and comics in order to reach my goal. The first book I finished in 2013 was Life of Pi by Yann Martel. I actually started this book in 2012 and finished it on January 1st.. In a way this doesn't really count, but who cares? After that I picked up Artemis Fowl by Eoin Colfer, an interesting children's book but I probably won't read the rest of the series. Before diving into Prodigy by Marie Lu, I read the little novella Live Before Legend. I started reading A Storm of Swords by George R.R. Martin in the middle of December and about 4 month later I managed to finish it. Whereas A Storm of Swords took forever because it's over a 1 000 pages long, Beautiful Darkness took me forever to finish because I simply didn't like it. After those two, I was in the mood for something a lot lighter and something that I knew I would like: The Golden Lily by Richelle Mead. I quickly read Linchin by Seth Godin for my marketing class and flew through Paper Towns by John Green in 4 days! Then I also read the beautiful Inside HBO's Game of Thrones. My least favorite book of 2013 was probably World War Z by Max Brooks. It is after this that I started picking up some graphics novels and comics. My first graphic novel was Lost at Sea by Bryan Lee O'Malley and I also read the first 3 Scott Pilgrim graphics novels by the same author. Since I love the TV Show The Walking Dead, I decided it was time to read the comics as well and I read the first 3. Other graphics novels and comics I picked up were Coraline by Neil Gaiman and the first two Amoras comics by Marc Legendre. Back to books: one of my favorite books of this year is The Knife of Never Letting Go! I also got this book signed by the author Patrick Ness at a book fair, yay! I also picked up Harken by Kaleb Nation and continued the Bloodlines series by reading The Indigo Spell by Richelle Mead. My absolute favorite book of this year was The 5th Wave by Rick Yancey! Such a great read! I also read Fallen in Love and Rapture right before I had the opportunity to interview author Lauren Kate! Starcrossed by Josephine Angelini was up next. Over that same period of time I read another book in the Song of Ice and Fire series: A Feast for Crows. This one took me almost 5 months (including breaks from reading the book) to finish. After that I needed a quick read and I picked up Allegiant by Veronica Roth. This is the last book in the Divergent trilogy and I was surprisingly ok with how it ended. This was also the last book I managed to finish this year. I'm currently reading two books that I was unable to finish before the start of the new year and those are Burn Your Portfolio by Michael Janda and An Abundance of Katherines by John Green. I'm a bit disappointed in myself that I had to reduce my reading goal, but at the same time 30 books/graphic novels isn't bad at all. I also read two more books in the Song of Ice and Fire series and those are huge... So I do think that counts for something. I don't think 2013 was my best reading year, but I do like that I started reading some graphic novels and comics. I'm not sure what my reading goal for 2014 is going to be, but I'll probably set it to 30 books again. How was 2013 for you reading wise? What's your (least) favorite book of 2013? Enjoy New Years Eve and best wished for 2014!

item.title: Books I Own but Haven't Read Yet
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
My to-be-read list includes 144 books and counting. Even though the list always seems to grow rather than shorten, I usually don't allow myself to buy any new books until I've finished the ones that I already own. And then I lived in London for 3 months and I was confronted with bookstores everywhere. So yeah, I collected my fare share of books in London. That combined with some books that I already owned before I left for London, creates todays blog. Here are the books that I own, but have yet to read.

Inferno & The Lost Symbol by Dan Brown

It's been a while since I've read a Dan Brown book. I bought The Lost Symbol when it first came out, but my mum started reading it before I could get around to it and it took my mum forever to finish it, so now I have yet to read both Inferno and The Lost Symbol.

Gerechtigheid by Stieg Larsson

I guess you could say that I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with Stieg Larsson books. I absolutely love the storyline and the characters but the books are just an overload of information. Some of that information is just unnecessary and with the first 2 books I skipped quite a few pages. I want to know how this story ends, but I'm honestly not sure when I'll have to courage to pick up this book!

The Ask and the Anwser & Monsters of Men by Patrick Ness

I loved the first book in the Chaos Walking trilogy and so when I went back to London in August of this year, I decided to pick these two up! I really looking forward to finishing this series!

Evermore, Blind Date & The Unbecoming of Mara Dyer

I bought Evermore at a book fair last year and I didn't get around to reading it before I left for London and it's still on my TBR pile. It's also in Dutch, which is probably another reason why I'm not that eager to pick it up. Blind Date & The Unbecoming of Mara Dyer are in Dutch as well. I received both books as a gift from a Belgian publisher. I really want to read The Unbecoming of Mara Dyer, but I haven't gotten around to it. Which book of this list do you think that I should read next? And what are some books on your TBR pile?

Evermore staat ook al een hele lang tijd in mijn kast maar ik heb hem nog steeds niet gelezen :p Hele mooie foto's trouwens!

Ik ben Feast for Crows ook nog aan het lezen. Ben er ongeveer voor 70% door nu. The Maze Runner is een leuk boek en misschien dat ik ook nog maar een Harry Potter re-read moet doen om mijn Goodreads challenge te halen!

item.title: Orphan Black (Season 1 Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Orphan Black starts off with a girl named Sarah, who is pulled into a conspiracy after witnessing the suicide of a girl who looks just like her. I had heard about this show before, but I never really took the time to see what it was about. Last week I was in the mood for something new and I ended up watching the show's first season in a few days. I won't tell you more about what the show is about, because I honestly think this is one of those shows where you have to go in blind. For those of you who'd like to know a little more, I'd suggest you watch the trailer. I doesn't give too much away, although you do get a few more clues. I didn't really know what to expect when I started watching this show, but it took me completely by surprise. I got sucked in right from the start and I couldn't stop watching. I watched all 10 episodes in 4 days. I would've finished it faster if I didn't have anywhere to be. I was on the edge of my seat pretty much the whole time. I want to praise Tatiana Maslany for a second. What she pulls of in this show is unbelievable. She takes on so many characters with the same face and yet you're never confused as to who is who. It's hard to say who this show is for but if you like a bit of Sci-Fi combined with lots of action and drama, then you're good to go! The second season starts airing in April 2014, so you should have plenty of time to catch up! Do it, because this is honestly one of the best shows I've seen in a while. If you've seen Orphan Black, let me know what you think about the show in the comments. If you haven't seen it, are interested in watching it?

item.title: How I Live Now (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
How I Live Now tells the story of an American girl who is forced to move in with relatives in England. While she's there, the 3rd World War is happening around her and there aren't any adults around. This movie is based on a book by Meg Rosoff. I haven't read the book (yet), but based on the movie it would seem that it's something I should do. Pretty much right from the beginning of the story, you realise that there's something up with Daisy (played by the amazing Saoirse Ronan). She's hearing voices or at least remembering some rules that she feels she has to follow. Daisy certainly is an interesting character and I think that Saoirse Ronan portrayed her very well. Seeing her relationship form with her cousins and even the bit of odd incest happening, is an interesting part of the story. How I Live Now is rather slow paced, but that never really bothered me while watching the movie. Although I can imagine that this might put some people off. The thing is, there's a war happening, but you only experience what Daisy experiences. So yes, there are some cruel thing happening, but all of this is rather emotional and dramatic instead of being action-packed. I was invested in Daisy and the other characters and I was rooting for them to find their way back to each other. Was this the best movie of 2013? No, but I did enjoy it. It was interesting. There's some stuff that's hinted at or implied. In a way there's a bit of a sci-fi/fantasy thing going on, which apparently isn't even in the book. I don't think this movie is for everyone, but if you're into some more alternative movies this might be something for you. How I Live Now has a bit of a more artistic touch to it. It's a bit dark and emotional. I honestly think it's worth watching.

Have you seen How I Live Now or read the book? Let me know your thoughts about the movie in the comments!

Trailer | IMDb | Buy the book

item.title: Burn Your Portfolio (Book Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I first heard about Burn Your Portfolio: Stuff They Don't Teach You in Design School, But Should by Michael Janda in Web Designer Magazine. I pointed it out to one of my bosses and he ordered it for me pretty much straight away. In Burn Your Portfolio, Michael Janda goes more in depth about what it takes to be a professional designer/developer. It's not just about having an amazing portfolio and knowing how to design or build a website, it's also about communicating with your team, clients and so much more. Janda uses a lot of anecdotes and references from his own experiences, which makes it feel more like you're learning from someone else's successes and failures, rather than being told what to do. Not all the information in this book was new to me, but I think this book overall was just a great reminder. A reminder of staying positive, a reminder of how to interact with clients. I may only have just started my first full-time job, but I've had plenty of previous experiences to know that clients can be a pain sometimes. However, I sometimes also forget that most of them don't have clue about what it takes to design or build a website. Burn Your Portfolio reminded me of that and many other things. I'm not going to summarize all the different chapters and tips, but I think that this book is a must-read for everyone in the design or development industry. Whether you're just out of school, already have years of experience or run your own business. This book contains information for all different kinds of perspectives. As a business owner your can get a lot of useful information out of this book and as an employee, you get an idea of what it takes to run a design company. And well, aside from being a really interesting read, this book is simply beautiful. There are a lot of fun illustrations in this book, which makes reading it, all the more enjoyable. I'm actually quite sad that I have to take this book back to the office, because I would love to have it on my own bookshelf. Aside from being beautiful, this is the kind of book that you need to pick up every once in a while and read a chapter or two, just to remind and inspire yourself.

Let me know in the comments if you've read the book or if you're interested in picking it up!

Buy on Bol.com | Buy on The Book Depository

item.title: The Book Thief (Book + Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I had heard about The Book Thief by Markus Zusak plenty of times before, but it was only after seeing the trailer for the movie that the story really caught my attention. With the movie being out already in several countries, I figured I should pick up the book and read it before seeing the movie. I didn't know what to expect, but what I received was a beautiful and heartbreaking story that got me thinking. The Book Thief tells the story of Liesel Meminger. Or rather, Death tells the story of Liesel. Liesel lives in Nazi Germany with her foster parents and after the death of her brother, she picked up the habit of stealing books.

The book

The reason that I had put off reading this book for so long is because of the subject: World War II. However, The Book Thief is not just any book about the war. This book is narrated by Death. Death is suddenly a character. A character that acts, thinks and observes. The perspective you get on the story is so incredibly interesting and for me, unlike anything I've ever read before. It took me a few pages to get used to the way the story is written, as well as with the fact that Death spoils the rest of the story on a regular basis by announcing someone's death a few pages before it actually happens. This alone makes this book an interesting and captivating read. And then there's Liesel, her foster parents, Max, Rudy and so on. The characters in this book are a joy to read about. They are flawed, but yet they are beautiful. The story itself bring out so many emotions. In its own way The Book Thief gives you a gruesome peek into what life was like during that time. This book left me speechless and deep in thought for a moment after I finished it. I have a hard time trying find to words to describe this book, but this is a 'read it to believe it' kind of situation. This is the kind of book that leaves a mark and I won't soon forget.

The movie

And then there's the movie. It probably wasn't the best thing that the book was so fresh in my mind, because I missed a lot in the movie. Yes, I know that book-to-movie adaptations like "The Hunger Games: Catching Fire" are rare, but there are some beautiful moments from the book that didn't make it into the movie. Nothing I can really be mad about though, since the movie is already two hours long. Looking at the movie in itself though, it was great! The story of The Book Thief was portrayed beautifully. I'm also glad that they kept Death as a narrator. I loved seeing all of the characters come to life and I think the whole cast did a wonderful job. Looking at all of the book-to-movie adaptions we've had to endure over the past few years, I definitely think that this is one of the better ones.

Conclusion

I can definitely recommend both the book and the movie. You'll probably enjoy the movie more without reading the book, but then again you'll also miss out on all the beautiful moments that didn't make it into the movie. Whatever you decide, this is a story that you need to read or see.

Buy the Book | Watch the Trailer

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Book Thief Book and Movie Review

item.title: The 100 (Pilot Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The CW's new show "The 100" premiered earlier this week. The 100 is actually one of the few new show of the The CW that I decided to check out. The CW has a habit of disappointing me by using a story with great potential, casting actors that can't really act and writing terrible plot and dialogue. I decided to give The 100 a try, simply because the overall world and storyline seemed interesting. I'm yet undecided on wether or not this show is going to be any good. The 100 takes place in the future, where humanity is trying to survive on an ark in space. Resources on the ark are running low and that's why they send a hundred juvenile delinquents back to earth to see if the planet has restored to health and is habitable. When you take a first look at the cast (even without seeing the first episode or a trailer), it's pretty easy to tell that these people aren't going to be the most outstanding actors. I actually remember Eliza Taylor (Clarke Griffin in The 100) from shows that I used to watch when I was little (The Sleepover Club and Pirate Islands) and I've seen Marie Avgeropoulos (Octavia) in another CW show, Cult. Among the adult cast there are some actors that I do like from their previous work: Isaiah Washington (Grey's Anatomy), Henry Ian Cusick (Lost) and Paige Turco (Person of Interest). Cusick's American accent sounded pretty terrible though. I wish they would've let him keep his awesome Scottish accent. But as expected, the cast didn't blow me away in this first episode, but I've also seen worse. As for the story so far, I mostly like the world building. As with many CW shows, the overall storyline has a lot of potential. The set-up with a hundred people younger than 18 being sent to earth is rather interesting. All of them committed some kind of crime, so there's bound to be chaos over the coming season. In the pilot they hinted that there's a population of natives on earth that aren't going to make it easy for those teens. I'm a bit skeptical about this as there's a very big chance that these natives won't be very interesting at all. I hope that these natives won't just be attacking for no reason. Anyway, as you can tell I'm not yet convinced about The 100. I am going to continue watching for now, in the hopes that it'll get a least a bit good. I can't quite say wether or not you should check the show out, as I think that's something that depends a lot on how much you enjoy CW tv shows.

What about you? Have you seen the pilot of The 100? What are your thoughts? Or do you plan on checking the show out?

(PS: sorry about the lack of blogs these past few months. I've been working on a new design, which is taking priority over writing at the moment.)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The 100 Pilot Review | Joyce Van Herck

item.title: Divergent (Movie Review)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was lucky enough to be invited by BelgaFilms (Belgian movie distributor) to an advanced screening of Divergent, allowing me to be one of the first people in Belgium to see the movie. I went in with low expectations, because I thought most of the trailers made the film look terrible. I came out being thoroughly entertained and relieved that Divergent turned out to be a good movie. Divergent is based on the YA novel by Veronica Roth (as if you didn't already know that). I assume that most of you reading this know what the book/movie is about, but in case you don't, you can read a short summary on IMDb. This review contains spoilers for those who have not read the book, as well as a small quote from the movie (although I don't think it'll spoil the movie for you). The best way to describe my overall thoughts on Divergent is as follows: Divergent is not as good of an adaptation as "Catching Fire", but it's not as bad as "The Host" or "City of Bones". It's been a while since I last read Divergent, so I was quite fuzzy on all of the details going into the movie (which I think is a good thing). This allowed me to look at the movie without comparing it with the book the whole time and as a film on its own, Divergent is actually good. I've certainly seen worse over the past few years. It was only after seeing the movie that my friends and I tried to think of things that were left out or changed, but nothing we came up with was something that I could be really mad about. With book to movie adaptations there are just always changes. Sometimes they get it very right, sometimes they get it very wrong. I think Divergent is somewhere in between. As for the dialogue, the only sentence I really had a problem with was the "I don't want to move too fast"-line (or something like that), which only makes sense once you see Tris' final fear landscape. When it comes to the cast, I am extremely happy with everyone. I think Shailene Woodley as Tris was just perfect. She's such a natural actress and the moment when Tris' mum gets killed is flawless! When Theo James was cast as Four, I wasn't convinced right away. Turns out I just needed to see him act, because he was able to pull of Four's character just right! I'm also really happy with the way that Zoë Kravitz portrayed Christina. All of the cast just did a great job in my opinion. As a fan of the book, I can honestly say that I'm very pleased with the way that Divergent turned out. I do wonder if I'll feel the same way after re-reading the book and then seeing the film again, but that's an issue for another time.

Let me know your thoughts on Divergent in the comments or tell me when you plan on seeing it!

item.title: Starting Over
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hi and welcome to my new domain joycevherck.com! Those of you who have been following my blog on my previous domain (memorable-design.net) may be wondering what happened, so I thought it seemed only fair to explain the sudden move. So what happened? Your old domain still exists? Why doesn't it redirect? Why isn't there a blog on there announcing the domain change? Well, that's because I'm locked out of the damn site.

Fansite hosting

I had that domain for almost 7 years now. I started that site right around the time that I started my very first fansite and so I decided to make use of so-called fansite hosting. There are several services on the internet that offer free hosting for fansites and because I owned a fansite, I could also host my personal site with those same services. At the time I also posted a lot of fanart, which made my site fit into the "fansite" category. Since the very start of my site, I was hosted with FanFusion. They also own that domain. When I first started with my site nothing seemed wrong with the hosting, but when you Google them now, there are a lot of sketchy stories showing up. I never really had any problems with the host. Every once in a while my site would be down, which was annoying, but, hey, I didn't have a pay anything, so I didn't think about it. Until a few weeks ago when it all went to hell.

Where it went wrong

I was working on the new design of my site (the one you're seeing right now), but I couldn't login to my FTP or control panel anymore. I just figured that I'd misplaced the password or changed it and had forgotten about it. Guess not. I made several attempts to contact FanFusion. First a friendly request to change my password. When I, however, didn't get any reply to that, a less friendly email. I suppose that that's where I went wrong, because the next day I couldn't even login into my Wordpress anymore. So I'm pretty much locked out of my own website. I can't delete any of the content. Can't post a blog to let me readers know that I've moved. Can't redirect the site to this new one. So I simply didn't have any other choice, but to move to a new domain. I don't mind the new domain name (I was getting kind of sick of the old one), but I do mind that I can't delete anything from the old one. It sucks because when you Google my name, the old site is the first thing that comes up. Oh well... it's out of my control, so there's no point in worrying about it. Lucky enough, I was able to save my fansite District12.be (I do own that domain name) just in time and was able to move the hundreds of posts and photos to a new server.

So what about all the content?

I was lucky enough to have quite a recent back-up of all of my posts. The photos where a bit of a different story. I wasn't able to rescue every single post, because I didn't have some of the photo collages I had made. Most of my blog posts are on this new site though. I didn't lose anything important.

What now?

Well, I'm starting over and moving on. I hope I'll be able to get most of my readers back, but no matter the visitor count these first few months: I will get back to blogging and vlogging!

The new design

As you can see moving to a new domain also meant that I had to fastforward my work on the new design in order to get this site back up and running asap! That also means that not everything is 100% done yet. I'm pretty sure that there'll still be some small changes here and there of the coming weeks. I also have yet to test the site in IE8, which I'm guessing is going to be a pain. But other than that, my site is fully functional and responsive. There could, however, still be some dead links in the older blog posts (I went through them all, but I might have missed some links here and there). And not to forget: the picture of the Antwerp skyline was made by my friend, Max Veale.

Bloglovin'

For those of you who were following me on Bloglovin' before, I'd love if you'd follow my again at this new domain. You can click the button below to do so.

What do you think of the new design? I'd love to hear your thoughts/feedback!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That just sounds messed up, hope fanfusion will go down one time because this is wrong. A fresh new start is the best thing to do yes, just too bad you can't save/delete some things of your previous domain! x Jessica
Wow, wat kut zeg! Dat ze dat zomaar doen. Gelukkig heb je alles van district12 kunnen redden! Nieuw domein, nieuwe start!
Oh en bijna nog vergeten te zeggen: je design is ZOOOOOO tof!
Dank je Sarah :D

Ja ik vroeg me al af wat er was gebeurd! Ik was al eerder wezen kijken en kwam niet uit op je blog. Maar ik ben er! Ik ga overigens ook maar overstappen want er is ook steeds iets met mijn server, vet irritant!

Ik wilde ook nog even zeggen (sorry laat) dat je design prachtig is! Echt ontzettend tof, ziet het er uit. Vind ook echt dat je een hele fijne eigen stijl hebt. Wel heel erg rot dat ze je website zomaar zo 'verwijderen'.
Bedankt Nieke! Dat is heel erg fijn op te horen! :D

item.title: Justin Timberlake & The Tennessee Kids @ Sportpaleis Antwerp
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
When I got my first salary at the end of September, I knew what I was going to spend it on (or part of it anyway): Justin Timberlake tickets! I actually found out that there was a Mastercard pre-sale for the show on his website, which meant getting my tickets about 5 days early! May 1st... the day had come! It was time to see Justin Timberlake & The Tennessee Kids in concert.  I went to the concert with a friend of mine and we wanted to get there early enough to get a decent spot. We went for a little bite to eat and joined the queue in front of the concert hall after that. Once we got inside it turned out that we could still get a great spot close to the stage and I'm pretty sure we moved a couple of rows ahead throughout the show as well. The show started with a little intro video and a countdown! That countdown brought out the fangirl in me and suddenly got me very excited for the show to start. The countdown ends, the intro of Pusher Love Girl starts and silhouettes of Timberlake and The Tennessee Kids appear on the screen. And the screaming! Wow! It was a little bit how I imagine a One Direction concert to be non-stop. Luckily, after everyone got over their little fangirl/boy moment, they were able to listen, sing along and dance (except for those girls around us who watched most of the show through their phones, recording everything). Anyway, I'm not going to go through all of the songs he performed, but I will say that I had a hell of a good time! And from the looks of it everyone on that stage and around me did too. Old songs, new songs, it didn't matter! Everyone stayed excited from the first to the last song. It was a hell of a party. A part of the show that I will mention is the moving stage! Part of the front stage was able to move all the way to the back of the concert hall. Justin, his back-up singers and his dancers were able to move from left to right and that way the people in the tribunes and the back of the room were able to see JT up close for a few songs as well. Smart move from whoever came up with that idea. Some people around me were whining when he got to this little stage in the back to play a few songs. I say that the people in the back have just as much right to see him up close as anyone. I had an absolute blast and it's definitely in my top 3 concerts! It was fun to hear slightly different versions of his old hits, the dancing was flawless and also hats off for The Tenessee Kids because they were amazing as well! So yes, very entertaining concert! I'll probably be listening to his music for the next couple of days.

Let me know if you've every attended a JT concert!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Justin Timberlake & The Tennessee Kids in Antwerp | Joyce Van Herck

item.title: I'm Moving to London!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The secret has been out for a while now. If you follow me on social media or know me in real life then you probably already know, but I realised that I never really made an official announcement so here it is: I AM MOVING TO LONDON!

Why are you moving to London?

As you probably already know, I lived in London for 3 months last year while doing an internship at Go Up and ever since then I've wanted to go back. After I finished my internship, it looked like Go Up might offer me a job, but in the end they didn't for financial reasons. When I was job hunting over eight months ago, I applied to agencies in Belgium and London. I, however, should've realised that not many agencies would take the risk or be interested in hiring someone that doesn't even live in the same country. And so I took the job at BLEND, where I've worked for the past eight months and only have one week left. I kept finding myself wanting to return to London. I went back a few times and that seemed to help, but only temporarily. My friend Nieke, who lives in London, kept me updated on the vacancies at the agency where she works and in the end that sort of forced me to finally make a decision. And so I did. I decided to take the risk and move without even having a job. But as everyone keeps telling me: now is the time to try this. If I fail, I fail, but at least I will have tried it and I won't be wondering for the rest of my life.

So what's the plan? Do you have a job?

I don't have a job yet, but I have been sending out applications. My moving date is set, so I just mention in every application that I'll be able to come by for an interview once I've moved. So far, I already have two interviews planned, which is making me relax a bit more. I also have a place to stay. I can stay in the same room as last year for three months, before I have to find something else. This also gives me the time to find a job first. The plan is to move with only the essentials at first. Then once I've found a job and a more permanent place to stay, I'll move the rest of my stuff out to London.

Wish me luck!

This is probably the scariest, craziest thing I've ever done. When I lived in London last year, everything was planned. I knew where I was going to do the internship, I had a place to live, financial support from school and my parents. The only thing I had to figure out was how to cook and keep myself alive. This time around I know more people who live in the city, I have a place to stay, but no job and therefore also a limited amount of money. I am a planner. I rarely do things or go places without planning as much as I think is necessary. This can't be planned and it's making me nervous. But I know I need to do this. I want to do this. And so I will. Wish me luck! I really do hope that I can last in this expensive city for a year or two. (PS: this is also the reason that I've been a bit MIA from blog-land for these past few weeks.)

item.title: The Start of a New Adventure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Oh boy, I did it. I moved to London! The past fews days (and weeks) have been so strange. I started packing up my things. Deciding what to take with me now and what can wait until I'm sure that I'll be staying in London. I met with my friends and said goodbye to family. Not fully realizing that I won't see them as often anymore. That I'll probably miss out on the already few family dinners we have each year. Missing out on fun nights out my friends will have without me being there. It is now my second day back in London. It's a bit strange and yet familiar to be back. For three months, I'll be staying in the same flat/room as last year. I'm really glad that's the case, because it felt a bit like coming home. I'm in a place that I'm already familiar with, as well as its surroundings. Yesterday and today consisted mostly of getting some things in order: unpacking, ironing the clothes that needed ironing, more unpacking, buying whatever I didn't bring with me (shampoo, conditioner and stuff like that) and food shopping. The weather in London has been amazing so far! It makes me want to go outside and do things, but it's not that easy. Everyone I know here has to work, so during the day I'm mostly on my own. I do want to walk around and discover London some more, but at the same time I also want to avoid places like Oxford Street and Westfield. I can't go around spending my money on things I don't need right now. That'll have to wait until I find a job. Today, however, I did return to Go Up, the agency were I did my internship, and met some of my former colleagues for lunch! It was only an hour or so, but it was great seeing them nonetheless. And hey, I'll be seeing much more of them in the coming days, weeks and months. Anyway, the weekend is almost here, so I'm sure I'll be meeting up with some more people. And then next week I'll be plenty busy with job interviews and preparing for them. I'll also need to get some papers in order, open a bank account and just all the things that you need to do when you move to another country. I just thought that I'd keep you updated on what's been going on. I'll keep you posted on the job hunting situation, but be sure to follow me on Twitter for some smaller updates and on Instagram for some London pics! Talk to you soon!

item.title: InstaDiary: July 2014
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I wonder if these InstaDiaries are still going to be interesting now that I've moved to London, as I appear to mostly post photos of the different places in London that I went to. As you will see as you scroll down, July was all London photos with some shots from London Film and Comic Con mixed in. [caption id="attachment_3847" align="alignnone" width="640"] Streets of London[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3848" align="alignnone" width="640"] Sunset[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3849" align="alignnone" width="640"] Burgers in the park![/caption] [caption id="attachment_3850" align="alignnone" width="640"] My photos with Lena Headey and Summer Glau[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3851" align="alignnone" width="640"] Game of Thrones cosplayers at LFCC[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3852" align="alignnone" width="640"] On the Iron Thrones as Beth Greene from The Walking Dead[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3853" align="alignnone" width="640"] With a male Tomb Raider[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3854" align="alignnone" width="640"] Evening walk[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3855" align="alignnone" width="640"] Comparison of my Beth Greene cosplay[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3856" align="alignnone" width="640"] I ate lobster for the first time[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3857" align="alignnone" width="640"] In Notting Hill[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3858" align="alignnone" width="640"] Canary Warf[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3859" align="alignnone" width="640"] Greenwich[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3860" align="alignnone" width="640"] Primrose Hill[/caption] [caption id="attachment_3861" align="alignnone" width="640"] Classic London![/caption] [caption id="attachment_3870" align="alignnone" width="640"] Bathroom art in Camden[/caption]

Two InstaDiaries in a row! I'm hoping to get some new stuff up for you guys soon! Stay tuned!

item.title: Cosplay: Beth Greene from The Walking Dead
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Moving to London brought another new adventure into my life: cosplaying. My friend Nieke got me into cosplay and when I moved I decided to give cosplaying a shot! I was quite nervous to start. Since I don't know how to sew, I decided to start with something were I could buy most things. I looked at a lot of different characters from a lot of different movies and tv shows, but ended up going for Beth Greene from The Walking Dead. The tops and jeans are from Forever21 and the shoes and accessories were bought from eBay. I then tea dyed the clothes and applies other techniques to make them look more worn and dirty. I also made adjustments to the necklace and made a few bracelets. On the day, I aplied some make-up to make my face and arms look dirty. And I can tell you that I got some really weird looks on my way to the convention. Here are some photos that Nieke made: There's a big chance that I will be wearing this cosplay again and making some adjustments to it. I think the clothes could look a bit more worn and I'm considering to add some fake blood in the mix. This would be a nice cosplay to do in a Walking Dead group someday as it's not as recognizable on its own. It was very exciting however that Jane McNeill (who played Patricia in the show) recognized my cosplay!

Feel free to let me know your thoughts and tips about this cosplay down below in the comments!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Even though it might not be 'very recognizable' without a group, I still think you nailed it! You looked awesome :)
Thanks Dani <3
Love it, leuk dat je haar hebt gekozen XD

item.title: Cosplay: Margaery Tyrell in Game of Thrones Photoshoot
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: On my birthday I received the wonderful opportunity to be part of a Game of Thrones Photoshoot, organised by Cosplay Shoots. They got a group of amazing cosplayers together, Angels Costumiers provided us with brilliant costumes and combined it made for a unique birthday! The entire day was absolutely amazing and I'm certainly tempted to create my own Margaery cosplay now (I need to learn how to sew first though). Also, more cosplay posts will follow!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Margaery Tyrell #GameOfThrones Cosplay | Joyce Van Herck

item.title: Cosplay: Lara Croft from Tomb Raider
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: It is time for some more cosplay! October 2014 was a busy cosplay month with not one, but two conventions. I debuted a few new costumes and this is one of them: Lara Croft. I've been a huge Lara Croft fan ever since I was a child, so it seemed only right to cosplay one of my favorite characters of all time. I based myself on Lara's more classic outfit (mainly using reference images from Tomb Raider Anniversary) and a more winter-friendly version of her look. The clothes were all bought on eBay. The wig is from Wig is Fashion and styled by myself. I bought toy guns and spray painted them. The belt, belt buckle and holsters were made by myself. Photography by Kaiju Industries I would love to do more Lara Croft cosplays in the future!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lara Croft Tomb Raider Cosplay | Joyce Van Herck

item.title: Cosplay: Cameron Phillips from Terminator
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Who doesn't want to be a Terminator for a day? I've always been a bit of a Terminator fan, especially of the TV Show and so when I had some time left before the October cons, I decided to work on a Cameron Phillips cosplay. The clothes are from Primark and eBay. The mask was made by myself out of Worbla. More photos on Facebook

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Cameron Phillips, Terminator Cosplay | Joyce Van Herck

item.title: A Few More Photos of my Beth Greene (The Walking Dead) Cosplay
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I know I shared some pictures of my Beth Greene cosplay before, but I just had to share these. Back in October I did a photoshoot with Kieran from So Say We All in Richmond Park and I absolutely love these photos! I will be wearing Beth again at London Film & Comic Con on Sunday as part of a bigger Walking Dead group. I'm also quite tempted to cosplay one of her other outfits if I were to ever be part of another TWD group.

item.title: Cosplay: Rapunzel in The Walking Disney group
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This cosplay group turned out to be unexpectedly popular at MCM October 2014. All of us were just looking for a fun and relaxed group, but our day ended up being very busy with shoot after shoot. I had an absolutely amazing time with all these ladies and especially during our shoot with Kaiju Industries! Oh and let's not forget that this group wouldn't have existed without this brilliant artwork by Kasami-Sensei More photos on Facebook. You'll also find links to the other cosplayers in this group on there.
